title: Farm House Kitchen
creator: Sanchez, Lawrence
description: A painting of the corner of a room that contains two windows, a porcelain sink set in a crudely made green cabinet that has a plywood counter top.  On the wall above the sink is a small cabinet with a box of corn flakes (cereal) on top of it.  A dish, a tin can and a cooking kettle sit on the counter top to the left of the sink.  A milk bottle is in the sink and a yellow dish pan, a knife, a glass mug, a paper cup, and a can of scouring powder are on the counter top to right of the sink.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow at the Wagner Gallery, Austin, TX, March 26, 1980. On frame:  Lawrence J. Sanchez, 905 N.E. 15th, Grand Prairie, Farm House Kitchen. Tag hanging on wire:  Lawrence Sanchez "Farm House Kitchen" acrylic on panel 250.00.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: The Voice Of The Drum Circles The Sun
creator: Hill, Joan
subject: Creek; Cherokee
description: A stylized painting of a man (facing the viewer) painted against a black hillside.  His black trousers and black coat blend with the background and are not visible.  He is wearing a wide brimmed high crowned white hat, a black coat with a fur collar, a white shirt, and two rows of conchos around his waist.  A long white scarf is draped over his left arm and he holds a drumstick in his left hand.  In his right hand he holds a drum and he appears to be singing.  The sky above the hill is red with a white moon (to viewer's left).
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow at the Five Civilized Tribes Museum's Master Art Show, September 20, 1981. This painting received the Grand Award at the Five Civilized Tribes Museum's 1981 Master Art Show, September, 1981. On painting stretcher:  "The Voice Of The Drum Circles The Sun" acrylic 32 X 36 Joan Hill Chea Se Quah  79 & 81  Creek & Cherokee. Taped to back of frame:  "The Voice Of The Drum Circles The Sun"  Drums were believed to be sacred or mysterious having great power because of the spiritual nature attributed to music.  The drum represented all of life's forces and its rhythm was symbolical of the rhythm of the entire universe   the heart throb of all creation.  Music marked every occasion of the Indian's life whether large or small, happy or sad, important or unimportant and no occasion was complete without the drum.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow at the Total Arts Gallery, Taos, NM, May 13, 1980.  This was one of three paintings purchased at this time - two by Gonske and one by Rod Gobel. title: Morning Hike In The Tetons
creator: Shaffer, Phillip
description: It is a painting of a landscape of mountain scene done in brown tones.  Aspen trees frame a mountain peak.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Zarrow at Four Seasons Gallery, Jackson, WY, Sept. 21, 1987. Taped to dust cover: Sept. 21, 1987; Morning Hike In The Tentons; 8X10 sepia watercolor; "I tried to capture the suspense and the surprise that waits the hiker as he rounds the next bend ni the trail." title: untitled - 4 eagle dancers, two singers, two drummers
creator: Pena, Tonita/Quah Ah
subject: San Ildefonso
description: A painting of a Pueblo eagle dance.  There are four dancers - two men and two women.  The men wear traditional eagle costumes and the women traditional white hand-woven one-shoulder dresses with eagle feather headdresses.  They are grouped to the viewer's left - two face right, 2 face left.  Facing them on the viewer's right are two females holding bows and arrows.  They appear to be singing.  Behind them are two drummers wearing "war" bonnets.  They hold the drums with their left hands and beat them with a drumstick held in their right hands.  The singers and drummers face the viewer's left.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow from Howard Huston of Hurst, TX, who brought the paintings to their home, June 3, 1996.  This was one of four paintings purchased from him at this time.  The others were by: Mopope, Otis Polelonema, and Popovi Da.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Cochiti Pueblo Corn Dance - The Banner
creator: Pena, Tonita/Quah Ah
subject: San Ildefonso
description: A painting of a Pueblo Indian man dancing and carrying a decorated pole.  His hair is worn in a Pueblo hairstyle and he wears a pink shirt, beaded and fringed buckskin leggings, and beaded moccasins.  In addition he wears a turquoise necklace and a silver and turquoise concho belt.  Painting Ca. 1930
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow by mail from Gallery 10 in Scottsdale, AZ on April 17, 1991.  The painting was purchased by Gallery 10 from a Missouri couple.  They collected it in the 40s. On back of painting:  "Cochiti Pueblo Corn Dance The Banner"
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: untitled - Pueblo Indian woman in ceremonial dress
creator: Pena, Tonita/Quah Ah
subject: San Ildefonso
description: A painting of a Pueblo Indian woman dancer who is facing the viewer's left.  She is dressed in a white, one shoulder hand-woven embroidered dress and wears a red and black hand-woven sash around her waist.  In addition she wears an eagle feather headdress and holds two feathers in her right hand.  Around her neck she wears several turquoise necklaces.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow from the Four Winds Gallery, Inc., Pittsburgh, PA in December of 1994.

title: untitled - a child dressed as a Koshare clown (or Kossa)
creator: Gutierrez, Geraldine
subject: Santa Clara; San Ildefonso
description: A painting of a child wearing the traditional Koshare headdress and black and white body paint.  He faces the viewer and wears a hand-woven breechclout, a hand-woven sash and high topped dance moccasins.  Above his head is a sun symbol and underneath him are geometric designs that include two turtles.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow by absentee bid from a R.G. Munn auction held in Albuquerque, NM, February 5, 1995.  This was one of 15 paintings purchased at the auction.  Auction number (on tag on back of painting):  585

title: Mythical Pony
creator: Pop Chalee/Marina Lujan
subject: Taos
description: A painting of a gold colored horse with a billowing, flowing white mane and tail.  Its neck is arched and its eye size is exaggerated (large).
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow at Streets of Taos in Santa Fe, NM on March 28, 1992.  While visiting the store the Zarrows noticed this painting hanging back of the cash register and asked if it was for sale.  The woman said she guessed so and she sold it to them. On sale receipt:  Pop Chalee Mythical Pony; 1983 - 1989; 5 1/2" X 3 1/2"; original painting; tempera on French paper.

title: Study for Almost Paradise
creator: Spaulding, Don
description: A painting of two men riding horses and leading a packhorse, as they are about to cross a stream.  They are moving toward the viewer's left.  The man closest to the viewer's left is riding a paint horse and wearing an animal skin hat and fringed buckskin clothing.  Directly behind him is a man, riding an appaloosa (horse), who is wearing a black wide brimmed hat and buckskin clothing and looking back over his left shoulder.  The packhorse follows the second horse.  Both men carry rifles.  The trees in the background are all gold and yellow.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow at the Gilcrease Museum's annual American Art In Miniature exhibition in Tulsa, OK, November 14, 1989. On back of painting:  Property of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow, 2660 Birmingham Place, Tulsa, OK; Exhibited in "American Art In Miniature: 1989"; November 16 - December 18, 1989; Gilcrease Museum - Tulsa, OK; Study for "Almost Paradise"; by Don Spaulding oil

provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow from the artist, either at their home or from the artist's truck in the Five Civilized Tribes Museum, Muskogee, OK, ca. 1980.

title: untitled - fruit still-life
creator: Duecker, Otto
description: A still life painting of various fruit sitting on a table. A knife lies on the table in front of the Apple and plum.  (Photo Realism)
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow from Otto Duecker at his studio, Tulsa, OK, in November 1996.  This was just prior to his solo exhibition at the Holliman Gallery, Walter Arts Center, Tulsa, OK, which ran from November 3 to the 26th, 1996.

title: Winter in Taos
creator: Daughters, Robert
description: An impressionistic painting of a winter landscape.  The foreground is covered with snow with a road or trail, winding from the center bottom toward some trees that are depicted in shades of gold and orange.  Hills or mountains are suggested in the distance.

title: After the Gold Rush
creator: Love, Ralph
description: A painting of an old frame building that is in the slow process of collapsing with the weight of the years.  It appears to be located on a hillside in a high mountain valley.  To the viewer's left is a corner of another building.  Portions of two fences connect the two buildings.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow at the artist's studio in Temecula, CA, ca. 1980.  This was one of three paintings by Ralph Love that the Zarrows purchased: at this time.  The other two were "Grand Canyon" and "San Francisco.�  The total price for the three was $4,750.00. Ralph Love produced signed and numbered reproductions of this painting.  He gave Mr. and Mrs. Zarrow two copies, one of which is framed (4/450 JMZ.380) and one (3/450) is in drawer # 9 in the map cabinet in their storage room. On Stretcher:  "After The Gold Rush" #1614 '78 Ralph Love, Temecula, CA

title: Pony songs
creator: Creepingbear, Mirac
subject: Kiowa; Pawnee; Arapaho
description: A painting of overlapping images.  To the viewer's left and in the center is a horse that has images of a buffalo herd over lapping its hindquarters.  The herd appears to come from the viewer's upper right.  Behind the buffalo herd and above the horse is the upper portion of a man's face facing the viewer.  His hair streams away from his head and becomes part of the sky.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow at the Oklahoma Indian Art Gallery, Oklahoma City, OK, March 21, 1992. Previous owners:  This painting was originally purchased by Bob McCabe from Mirac Creepingbear in 1984.  It was in his collection until 1992 when the Zarrows purchased it.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Winter Landscape Below Taos Mountain
creator: Gobel, Rod
description: An impressionistic painting of a winter landscape.  The foreground is snow covered with patches of earth showing.  In the middle ground is a grove of trees with snow on them and in the distance a snow covered peak.
provenance:
Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow at the Total Arts Gallery, Taos, NM, May 13, 1980.  This painting was one of three purchased.  The other two paintings were by Walt Gonske. This painting was exhibited in "Tulsans Collect, Gilcrease Museum, Tulsa, OK, February 16 through April 15, 1990 
On stretcher: "Winter Landscape Below Taos Mountain�; 1978 Rod Gobel (signature).  Also stamped Rod Gobel Studio

title: The Healer
creator: Harris, Walt
subject: Otoe; Missouri
description: A painting of two men facing each other across a campfire.  One man is seated and wearing a buffalo headdress (medicine man).  The other man is crouched down and holds staff.  He is wearing a breach clout and beaded moccasins.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Zarrow at the Indian Paintbrush Gallery, Siloam Springs, AR, October 27, 1980.  This painting was one of 12 purchased at that time.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: March Storm - Truchas
creator: Fritzler, Gerald J.
description: A painting of a winter landscape.  The foreground is a hillside with patchy snow and a wire fence zig zaging across it.  There are buildings on the viewer's upper left and on the far left a figure with a red coat standing at the side of a building.  In the distance there are mountains with storm clouds above them.
provenance:

title: After Buffalo Meat
creator: Smith, Kevin Warren
subject: Cherokee
description: A painting done in a ledger drawing style, depicting an Indian man in a top hat (with feather attached to top) and carrying a peace pipe and pipe bag in his left hand and a collapsed umbrella (used as a cane) in his right hand.  He is leading a paint horse (orange and white with green tail).
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow at The Art Market, Tulsa, OK, January 2, 1999.  This painting was one of three purchased.  The other two were by Murv Jacob and Norma Howard.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Pokoni Tapushink Ikbi (Grandma Making Baskets)
creator: Rutledge, Catherine A. (Gates)
subject: Choctaw; Cherokee
description: A painting of an elderly woman wearing a scarf over her hair and a calico dress with a white apron.  She is seated on a blanket in a field facing the viewer.  On either side of her are double woven swamp cane (red, black and natural colors) baskets with lids.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow at the Five Civilized Tribes Museum's 14th annual exhibition, Muskogee, OK, October 19, 1980.  This painting was exhibited in that show.  One of three paintings purchased.  The others were by Nadine Marler and Ruth Cole. On label on dust cover (removed to artist's file):  Attach to entry; Artist: Catherine Rutledge; Title: Pokoni Tapushink Ikbi (Grandma Making Baskets)". Also taped to dust cover:  Pononi Tapushink Ikbi; (Brandma Making Baskets); Old Choctaw woman shown with a typical hamper type of basket, made of river cane which was split and dyed with natural dyes before weaving.  Choctaws made a variety of baskets which were used for everything from storage to winnowing grain.; Catherine Rutledge (signature)
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: untitled - farmhouse and windmill
creator: Garza, Manuel
description: A painting of a farmhouse and a small barn.  Behind the house is a windmill and water tank and further in the background are hills.  In the foreground and to the viewer's right is a large tree. Also in the foreground are wild flowers and a trail leading to a red gate and the farmhouse.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow at the Wagner Gallery, Austin, TX, March 22, 1980.  This was one of four paintings purchased.  The others are: two Garza paintings (A-236 and A-234), "The Drifter" by Duke Sundt, and "Mandan Dancer" by Lincoln Fox. On back of canvas:  "Manuel Garza #A-233"

title: Hosteen Nez
creator: Swanson, Ray
description: A portrait of a lightly whiskered grey haired man wearing an old wide brimed round crowned (uncreased) black hat that has a silver and turquoise band.  He faces the viewer's right and wears a turquoise nugget earing and a turquoise necklace.  His shirt is mauve velvet with silver buttons.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow at The Gilcrease Museum's annual exhibition "American Art In Miniature: 1991" wall sale, Tulsa, Oklahoma, November 1, 1991. Sticker on back of painting:  "The Gilcrease Museum, Tulsa, OK; B.91.291; Hosteen Nez by Ray Swanson; Exhibited in: "American Art In Miniature"  November 2 through December 15, 1991."

provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow at the Big Horn Gallery in Aspen, Wyoming, August 24, 1996.

subject: Navajo

description: A painting of a flat roofed (pueblo style) adobe building with three red chili pepper strings hanging by the two front doors.  Two large trees (cottonwoods) whose leaves have turned gold shade the building.  A black and white dog sits to the viewer's left of the building.

title: Superstition Sunrise
creator: McKenna, Kenneth
description: A painting of an Arizona mountain foothill scene with large rock cliffs and ridges in the background.  Multipul armed Saguaro cactuses bracket the foreground. provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow from Kenneth McKenna through correspondence, Jerome, Arizona, January 22, 1996.

title: Indian Princess
creator: Mauldin, Jane McCarty
subject: Choctaw

provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow at the Indian Paintbrush Gallery in Siloam Springs, AR, October 27, 1980.  This painting was one of twelve purchased from this gallery at the same time.

title: First Watch
creator: Seltzer, Steve
description: A painting of an Indian man sitting on a white horse at dusk.  The man and horse face the viewer's left and the man looks over his left shoulder.  In the background is a fire with three figures around it � two seated and one standing - and behind them are four teepees.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow from Steve Seltzer through by special order from Great Falls, Montana, June 10, 1983. On stretcher:  "First Watch" June 10, 1983; 24 X 36 oil; WS Seltzer, Great Falls, Montana.

title: untitled - man on horse, facing left
creator: Wieghorst, Olaf
description: A painting of a man on a horse (light orange color - Palomino?) that faces the viewer's left.  The man is wearing a cowboy hat, yellow neck scarf, a blue shirt, chaps, and spurs.  His western style saddle has tapaderos in place of wood stirrups.  The horses head us up and his left forefoot is raised.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow from Stan Weiner, their son's father-in-law, who lives in New York City, NY.  Mr. Weiner is also an art collector.  He had four similar paintings by Wieghorst and sold the Zarrows two of them.

title: untitled - man on horse facing the right
creator: Wieghorst, Olaf
description: A painting of a man on a gold colored horse (palomino).  They face the viewer's right.  The man is wearing a white cowboy hat, a yellow neck scarf, a blue shirt, and chaps.  He sits slumped in a western style saddle, which has tapaderos in place of wood stirrups.  A rope is tied to the swells of his saddle.  The horse has four white stockings and a white blaze that extends over its nostrils.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow from Stan Weiner, their son's father-in-law, who lives in New York City, NY.  Mr. Weiner is also an art collector.  He had four similar paintings by Wieghorst and sold the Zarrows two of them.

title: October on the Teton River, Montana
creator: Aspevig, Clyde

title: Aspens
creator: Wolfe, Wayne E.
description: A landscape painting of nine aspen trees at the edge of a meadow with mountain peaks in the background.  The aspen leaves are orange and gold and the meadow shows autumn colors.  In the middle ground are mountain slopes covered with an evergreen forest.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. alnd Mrs. Jack Zarrow at the Gilcrease Museum's eleventh annual "Rendezvous" exhibition, April 28, 1989.  Wayne Wolfe was the featured painter. creator: Desatnick, Mike J.
description: A portrait of a seated young, brown eyed, black haired woman holding a white cup in her left hand.  She faces the viewer and looks to her right.  She is wearing a red shawl and holds a part of a costume (feathers?) in her lap with her right hand.

title: War Whistle
creator: Wall, Ralph
description: A painting of the head and shoulder of an Indian man (Comanche) wearing a "war" bonnet who faces the viewer's left.  He has seven black stripes painted on the side of his face from his forehead to under his chin.  He is blowing what appears to be a bone whistle.  A shield with a bear painted on it covers his left shoulder.  The sky is stormy and a strong wind blows his hair and "war" bonnet to the viewer's right.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow from the artist, date unknown. See artist file for the story that goes with this painting. On back of painting:  "War Whistle"; Comanche; 1977; Ralph Wall (signature).

title: Preparing For the Dance
creator: Forbis, Steve
description: A drawing of a young boy in an elaborate headdress facing the viewer.  He wears four turquoise rings (two on each hand), a silver and turquoise bracelet on his right hand, a silver and turquoise bow guard on his left wrist and a turquoise nugget necklace.  His clothing consists of a multi-colored fringed kilt held up with a silver concho belt and high topped dance moccasins.  There is a red, green, and white hand-woven sash tucked through the concho belt.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow from the artist, Austin, Texas, as a special order, 1/4/94. See artist file for correspondence concerning this drawing.  On card glued to dust cover:  "Preparing For The Dance" by Steve Forbis colored pencil, Image 15" X ? 4" Jan. 1995.

title: Desba Singer
creator: Morrow, Claudine
description: A head and shoulder portrait of a young Navajo girl.  Her hair is pulled back in a traditional Navajo hairstyle (the chongo) and she wears a red blouse with a large turquoise and silver broach at the collar.  She faces the viewer and looks off to her right.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow by mail from La Galeria, Sedona, AZ, June 4, 1979.  On a trip to Sedona, Arizona they saw this painting in the La Galeria window and when they got home they contacted the gallery about it.  Subsequently they purchased it.  The gallery represented Ms. Morrow and the painting came directly from her to the gallery to the Zarrows.

title: Cooling Off
creator: Seltzer, Steve
description: A painting of two Indian men on horseback facing the viewer.  The horses (one white - viewer's right and one brown - viewer's left) are side by side and standing in a stream.  The Indian on the white horse is wearing a horned headdress and has a bow and arrow in a quiver across his lower back and a spear across the saddle in front of him.  The Indian on the brown horse is wearing braids and has a rolled up blanket around his waist.  The brown horse has feathers tied to his forelock.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow from Steve Seltzer by special order.  Received May 22, 1982. On back of painting:  Cooling Off 1982.

title: Sun Child
creator: Wall, Ralph
description: A painting of a Sioux woman sitting on a paint horse that is dreanking water in the middle of a stream.  A bay  horse, with a travois strapped to it, is to the rear of the first horse and is also drinking.  The paint faces to the right and the bay to the left. title: The Horse Thieves
creator: Seltzer, Steve
description: A painting of an Indian man riding a white horse and moving to the viewer's right.  The man is wearing a horned headdress and has a shield hanging on his back. Two more Indian riders are seen in the background herding horses.

title: Hopi Heritage
creator: Forbis, Steve
description: A 3/4 length portrait of a very young (3 or 4 Yr. old) black haired, brown eyed girl who faces the viewer's right.  She is wearing a black sleeveless dress and a hand-woven red, black, and green sash.  Around her neck she is wearing six strands of heshi and turquoise necklaces to go with her turquoise ear pendants.  Her right hand is touching the necklaces and her left is touching her belt.  Bird pottery designs are behind her in the lower 1/3 of the painting.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow at the Gilcrease Museum's annual "American Art in Miniature" wall sale, Tulsa, OK, November 9, 1996. On dust cover:  "Hopi Heritage" by Steve Forbis (Austin, Texas) medium: Prismacolor; Miniature Art Show; Nov 9 1996; Gilcrease Museum.

title: The Welcoming Committee
creator: Seltzer, Steve
description: A painting of two white men being approached by a party of Indians on horseback with a teepee village in the background.  There are three horses with the white men - two for riding and a packhorse.  One horse is grazing while its rider stands in front of it.  This rider has on a fur hat and wears a capote tied at the waist with a piece of red fabric.  In his left hand he holds a rifle as he holds the horses reins with his right.  The other white man is sitting on a horse that faces the viewer�s right as the man looks over his right shoulder at the advancing Indians.  The packhorse is to the rear and in back of the second horse.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow from artist, Steve Seltzer, Great Falls, Montana through the mail, August 16, 1977. On stretcher:  The Welcoming Committee"  W S S.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: The Sun Worshipper
creator: Seltzer, Steve
description: A painting of an Indian man sitting on a horse (facing viewer's right) with an Indian village (6 teepees visible) in the background.  He has his arms raised palms out wart.  There is a quirt hanging from his right wrist and a shield hanging across his back and behind his left shoulder.  There are a bow and arrows in quivers across the back of his saddle.  He wears red leggings.  The horse is gray.

creator: Mootzka, Waldo
subject: Hopi

He faces the viewer's right.  His body is decorated with red and yellow paint.

subject: Hopi

title: Straight Dance
creator: Riddles, Leonard/Black Moon
subject: Comanche
description: A painting of a male dancer facing the viewer's right.  He is wearing a pill box shaped fur hat with a trailer that goes halfway down his back, a pink shirt and blue pants with a wide beaded belt.  There is a yellow scarf at his neck and under it on his back is a bead decorated trailer that goes almost to the ground.  He is also wearing a red breechclout.  On his feet he wears beaded moccasins with tassels on the heel.  In his left hand he is holding a fan and in his right hand a decorated stick that he uses as a cane.
provenance: PURCHASED: by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow by absentee bid from a R.G. Munn Auction held in Albuquerque, NM, February 6, 1999. On dust cover:  "Straight Dance" Black Moon (Leonard Riddles); Comanche (1910 -     ). Taped to top of dust cover:

title: The Medicine Man�
creator: Roye, Burgess
subject: Ponca
description: A painting of the head and hands (facing viewer) of an Indian man in braids (beaded bands on braids).  His eyes are closed and his head slightly bowed.  His hands appear to reach out to a peyote bus at the lower edge of the painting.  There is a teepee behind and to the viewer's right of his head.
provenance: PURCHASED: by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow by absentee bid from a R.G. Munn auction (#508) in Albuquerque, NM, February 6, 1999. Taped to top of dust cover:  (ink cross marks through the following on a blue card). ATTACH TO TOP LEFT-HAND CORNER ON BACK OF ENTRY NAME Fred Beaver TRIBE Creek/Seminole, ADDRESS  224 W. Coal, TITLE:  Plains Indian Warrior, MEDIUM  Gouache  PRICE: OR VALUE IF NFS  125.00???M NO. 803 EXHIBITOR NO. 124, Glued to dust cover:  Saturday, 11/8/75, "The Medicine Man" Speak thus of him who was truly the director of all matters; when illness came he was called, when war lingered in air and the chief's gathered he sat among them.  All matters concerned was his also...in actuality his decision was final...thus, with his blessings his spirit would also, be a part of his blessings. Burgess Roye  11-7-75. Picture here, the medicine man blessing the coming in life and the part of life the peyote played among the Indian...again Burgess Roye.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

subject: Comanche

subject: Cheyenne; Arapaho; Sioux

title: Gathering Wild Onions
creator: Echohawk, Brummett
subject: Pawnee
description: A painting of a woman and two small children.  The woman (facing viewer) is kneeling at the edge of a stream, she has a knife in her right hand and a basket full of onions on her right side.  A small girl (2 or 3 years old) is standing at the woman's left side with her face tucked into the woman's shoulder.  To the woman's right and behind her is a little boy (toddler).  The woman is smiling at someone across the stream and the little boy is gesturing to that person.  In the background is a paint horse (facing the viewer's left) that is grazing.  There is an Indian woman�s saddle on him and a travois is attached to the saddle.  A dog lies behind the horse, under the travois.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow from Brummett Echohawk, Tulsa, OK, July 8, 1980.  This was one of 17 paintings by Echohawk purchased at this time. On invoice:  $100.00 gathering Wild onions, mini-painting; oil; art size:  4" X 6"; Painted in 1980.

title: Captain Jim, Pawnee Scout
creator: Echohawk, Brummett
subject: Pawnee
description: A waist up portrait of a Pawnee man facing the viewer.  He is wearing an elaborate beaded "winged" headdress with a blue bow in the center front.  There is a bear claw and bead collar around his neck.  He is wearing a blue shirt with a black tie (scarf).  In his right hand he holds a tomahawk with a metal head and in his left hand a feather fan.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow from Brummett Echohawk, Tulsa, OK, June 19, 1996.  One of nine paintings by Echohawk purchased from him at this time. Glued to dust cover (remnants of original dust cover): From the collection of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow, Tulsa, OK; Brummett Echohawk (signature) 19 June '96; 5" X 7"; Captain Jim - Pawnee Scout, Doctor (healed the sick); lived in Pawnee, OK.  Tempera, 5 X 7 #75; del. by Sally Selph 10/4/96 (framer?).
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: The Comanche Dance
creator: Montoya, Geronima  Potsunu
subject: San Juan
description: A painting of six dancers facing the viewer's left - three male - three female - arranged male-female-male-female-male-female.  Two of the male figures are wearing "war" bonnets and the third is wearing a roach headdress.  The women are dressed in the traditional Pueblo one-shoulder hand-woven dresses (each one a different color) with hand-woven sashes.  They also wear capes and carry arrows in each hand.  The first male dancer (on the viewer's left) carries a staff, the second one a rattle and the third a musical pipe.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow from the Dewey Gallery, Santa Fe, NM, February 13, 1992. On old dust cover:  Mrs. Montoya by  (Potsuna) 1952; Purchased: from Liane Adams, Santa Fe, NM April 1956. From original backing:  D.L. Rust, 10 Country Club Place, Bloomington, Illinois; The Comanche Dance; Geronima Montoya San Juan. On back of painting:  The Comanche Dance. Gallery Card:  "Ceremonial Figures"  Artist:  Geronima Montoya, San Juan; Medium: watercolor; Size:  4" X 7"; Number:  A1599-001; Price:  $850; Dewey Galleries, Ltd.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Ruling His Sun, Pawnee Warrior
creator: Echohawk, Brummett
subject: Pawnee
description: A scratchboard head and shoulder portrait of an elderly Pawnee man.  He faces the viewer and has a feather (horizontal) at the top of his head.  He is wearing earrings (round loop with dangles) and a bear claw and bead collar.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow from Brummett Echohawk, Tulsa, OK, June 19, 1996.  One of nine paintings by Brummett Echohawk purchased at this time. On dust cover:  "Ruling His Sun, Pawnee Warrior" lived to be 105 years old.  Fought in Battle of Massacre Canyon, Trenton, Nebraska 1872.  This was last battle between Indian Nations - Pawnee vs. Sioux.  Drawing black & white scratchboard 7" X 8 1/2" by 1955 Brummett Echohawk (signature) 19 June 1996 (acquired).
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Enchanted Forest
creator: Pop Chalee/Merina Lujan
subject: Taos
description: A painting of eight multi-colored horses and one colt running toward the viewer's left in front of nine stylized trees.  The background is brown.  There are birds above the trees and flowers on the ground.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. jack Zarrow from James Conlon, Santa Fe, NM, September 1992.  This is one of two paintings purchased at this time, the other one was by Ahwah Tsireh (Alphonso Roybal).

title: The Wild Ones
creator: Tahoma, Quincy
subject: Navajo
description: A painting of six wildly running (toward the viewer's right) powerful varicolored horses jumping over a large log while being chased by two men on horseback.  One of the men is waving a blanket while the other looks back and gestures for someone else to come on.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow from the Dewey Gallery, Santa Fe, NM, January 11, 1991.

title: Kiowa Dancers
creator: Williams, David/Tos-que
subject: Kiowa; Tonkawa; Apache
description: A painting of two dancers facing the viewer's left.  They are identical, both wear elaborate buffalo headdresses with seven feathers attached.  They hold a bow in their raised right hand and a bundle of hair in their left hand, which is hanging down.  They are wearing beaded buckskin kilts with metal tinklers attached to the hem, and dance moccasins with fur cuffs.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. jack Zarrow from Belink's Studio, Santa Fe, NM, 1981.  One of six paintings purchased at this time, the others were by: T. Vigil, A. Blackowl, S. Mopope, Beatien Yazz, and Gary Montgomery.

title: Man of Peace
creator: Henson, Brooks
subject: Cherokee
description: A painting of a man wearing a blue turban sitting under a tree (facing viewer's left).  He is gray haired and wears wire frame glasses.  His right arm is extended in front of him and a blue bird is sitting on his extended forefinger (hand size is slightly exaggerated).  His left hand rests on his knee.  Another blue bird sits on a bush just back of his left shoulder.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow at the Cherokee national Museum, "Trail of Tears Art Show", Tahlequah, OK, June 15, 1991. On backing:  Entry Five; Category: 1; Title: Man of Peace; Artist: Brooks Henson; Medium; Acrylic; Sale Price:  155.00  7/91  Tahlequah, Okla.  Also:  Brooks Henson Native American Art (Cherokee) (918) 266-4786 (918) 234-7079.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Singers and Dancers
creator: Henson, Brooks
subject: Cherokee
description: A painting of a group of people singing and dancing in a clearing in the woods.  In the foreground (viewer's right side)is a group of four people (three facing viewer's left, one with back to viewer) who are singing.  In the middle ground to the viewer's left is a single man in a white shirt (back to viewer) that is holding a rattle in his right hand.  Beyond him (to his right) are four men in white shorts that are dancing around a fire.  Each of these men holds a black staff.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow at The Art Market, Tulsa, OK, July 3, 1991. On old backing, attached to dust cover:  Singers & Cancers by Brooks Henson; 7/91; 125.00.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Big Spotted Horse, Pawnee Scout)
creator: Echohawk, Brummett
subject: Pawnee
description: A waist up portrait of a Pawnee man with long wrapped braids (facing viewer).  He is wearing a blue shirt and a pipe bone breast plate decorated with German silver and beading.  In the center of the breastplate is a triangular shaped piece with a horse drawn on it.  The man is holding a brass headed tomahawk in both hands - across his lap.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow from Brummett Echohawk, Tulsa, OK, June 19, 1996. On tape on stretcher:  Jack and Maxine Zarrow, Tulsa, OK; 7 1/2" X 9 1/2"; Big Spotted Horse, Pawnee Scout; Brummett Echohawk (signature) 19 June 1996.

creator: Chris
description: A painting of two fishing boats with a wharf in the background.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow on a wharf in San Francisco, CA, as a souvenir of their visit, ca. 1970.

title: untitled - Koshare coming out of a jar
creator: Gutierrez, Geraldine
subject: Santa Clara; San Ildefonso
description: A painting of a young looking Koshare clown coming out of the neck of a ceramic jar which is decorated with a water-serpent design.  The jar has a fluted rim.  There is a ladder leaning up against the back of the jar.  The Koshare clown faces the viewer and appears to be waving with his right hand.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow by absentee bid from a R.G. Munn auction in Albuquerque, NM, February 5, 1995.  Painting's auction number - #690. On Backing:  18.

title: Mimbres Polychrome Man
creator: Hardin, Helen
subject: Santa Clara
description: A geometric painting  with concentric circles filled with designs.  The center contains the stylized figure of a man (round head, square body) with arms raised and legs spread.  The colors are: metallic gold, brown, black, and blue.  The painting is done diagonally - as though painted on a diamond.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow at the Indian Paintbrush Gallery, Siloam Springs, AR, October, 18, 1991. On backing:  "Mimbres Polychrome Man" and sticker:  "Authentic Native American Art Exhibition; Artist:  Helen Hardin;  Title: Mimbres Polychrome Man; Medium: acrylic; 4/14/81. On invoice:  "Harden purchased by seller from Helen Harden in 1981 at a show in Houston, TX."

title: Sioux War Chief
creator: Pahsetopah, Loren
subject: Osage; Cherokee
description: A painting of an Indian man in full ceremonial regalia riding a paint horse in the snow (toward the viewer's right).  He is wearing a buffalo headdress with fully feathered trailers, bead decorated buckskin clothing, and fully beaded moccasins.  He holds the war bridle rein in his right hand along with a bead-decorated blanket.  In his left hand the Indian man holds a fur covered coup stick.  The horse has feathers tied to his forelock and tail.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow at Ruth�s Turquoise, an art store in a strip shopping center on East 21st Street, November 1, ca. 1989.  At that time they purchased five or six paintings by the Pahsetopah brothers � Paul and Loren.  They gave two of them to their children. On piece of mat glued to the dust cover:  "Sioux War Chief" by Loren Pahsetopah Osage 80.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Untitled (Pueblo women singers)
creator: Atencio, Gilbert Benjamin
subject: San Ildefonso
description: A painting of fourteen Pueblo women in three diagonal ranks or rows facing the viewer's right.   They are dressed in the traditional one shoulder hand-woven dresses with lace edged capes over their shoulders.  The dresses are tied at the waist with red, black, white, and green hand-woven sashes.  Each figure shows individual variations in the colors of her dress and cape as well as the jewelry she wears.  One figure (center front) is beating a drum, which she holds and the others are singing.  There are cloud and sun symbols in the sky.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow from Dewey Galleries, Ltd., Santa Fe, NM, April, 16, 1991.  This was one of two paintings purchased.  The other painting was by Joe Herrerra. Dewey Galleries, Ltd. gallery number (painting) AI C 342-1.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: The Rescue
creator: Tiger, Jerome
subject: Creek; Seminole
description: A painting of a man in fringed buckskin clothing, with a blanket wrapped around him, carrying a child in his arms as he climbs a snow covered hill.  He faces the viewer's right.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow from D.F. Henry Company, The Mobil Art Gallery, Tulsa, OK, December 14, 1980.  This was one of four paintings purchased at this time.  The others were by S. McCombs, A. Blackowl, and A. Blue Eagle. On Dust cover:  Tiger 1965 "The Rescue". Sticker on dust cover:  The Art Center, McAlester, OK.

title: Hodos Doodi (Canary Horse)
creator: Tsinajinie, Andrew Van
subject: Navajo
description: A painting of a paint horse violently running toward the viewer's left while his Indian rider looks back over his left shoulder.  There is a bow in the riders left hand and a fur-covered shield rests on his back along with a quiver full of arrows.  The man wears a red breechclout and has a scarf tied across his forehead.  His right hand holds the rein of the war bridle.  Dust billows around the horse and rider.  The painting was done on a brown background.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow from The Art Market, Tulsa, OK, March 7, 1991. Sticker on dust cover:  Given to Carolyn Marcia Heath 1979. Written on back edge of frame (top right corner):  79.137. On piece of mat board glued to dust cover:  Hodos Doodii; Canary Horse.  On back of Art Market business card glued to dust cover:  Andy Tsinajinie Hodos Doodii (Canary Horse).

title: Abstract Rainbird
creator: Velarde, Pablita
subject: Santa Clara
description: An abstract painting done in black, brown, gold, turquoise, and white.  A spiral figure (this shape is commonly used by Pueblo artists to depict a parrot) is located on the lower left (viewer's quarter of the painting.  Above it, also on the viewer's left, is a series of four ribbon like arching figures.  In the center of the top is a half circle that has the appearance of a half sun.  The viewer�s right side of the painting is filled in with geometric and pottery design forms.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow at Gallery 10, Scottsdale, AZ, December 1, 1990.  One of four paintings purchased at this time.  The others were by C. Bahnimptewa; Julian Martinez, and Gilbert Atencio. Data supplied by Gallery 10 in letter of authenticity (see artist's file):  Pablita Velarde, Abstract Rainbird.  Acrylic on illustration board.  Ex. collection Mr. and Mrs. Humlicek, Phoenix, AZ. On dust cover:  Abstract Rainbird; Pablita Velarde; Feb. 1991; Acrylic on illustration board; Ex. coll. Mr. and Mrs. Duane Humlicek, Phoenix, AZ.  Purchased from Gallery 10, Inc. AZ (David Stock).
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Winter Landscape, Cimarron Iron Bridge
creator: Echohawk, Brummett
subject: Pawnee
description: An impressionistic landscape painting of a triple arched iron bridge crossing a river.  The trees are bare and the ground on both ends of the bridge is covered with snow and the tire tracks show in the snow on the bridge.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow from Brummett Echohawk, Tulsa, OK, July 8, 1980.  This was one of 19 paintings by Echohawk purchased at this time. From artist' list:  "This iron bridge is one of the last of its kind, standing across the Cimarron River northeast of Oilton, Oklahoma."

title: Harvest Song
creator: Redbird, Robert, Sr.
subject: Kiowa
description: A painting of the head and shoulders of a man (facing the viewer's right) that appears to be floating in the top half of the painting.  He has long flowing hair and is wearing a wide brimmed lavender hat, turquoise earrings and three strands of turquoise beads.  He appears to be singing.  Below this figure is a ceramic jar and six apples.  This painting is an example of redbird's air-brush technique.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow from H. B. Balink of Balink�s Studio, Santa Fe, NM.  Purchased from Mr. Balink in Tulsa, January 1, 1989.

title: untitled - Venetian canal scene
creator: Vendramin, Loris
description: A painting of a Venetian canal.  The canal is in the middle with buildings up to its edge on both sides.  There are two bridges over the canal - one in the foreground, one in the background.  A rowboat is tied up at the right (viewer's side of the closest bridge.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow at the Scalella S. Zaecaria in Venice, Italy while on a trip, September 19, 1992.

title: If I Were A Tree
creator: Tye, Joe B.
description: A painting of a young boy (on viewer's right) with his arms out stretched (back toward the viewer) looking at a multitrunk tree (on viewer's left) which is bare of leaves.  In front of the boy is a plowed field with farm buildings in the background.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow at The Wagner Gallery, Austin, TX, March 26, 1980. A sticker on the back of the paintings says "If I Were A Tree" Feb   Mar & Nov '78; This painting utilizes acrylic polymer paints and finishes; to clean, use a soft rag and luke warm water; In extreme cases, a mild detergent may be used; Do not use any other chemicals.

title: Grandmother's Attic
creator: Hughes, Stan
description: A painting of a little girl sitting on the floor in the middle of trunks, an old radio, a copper tub full of magazines, a suitcase, an antique electric fan, a wicker trunk, and stacks of books.  She is dressed up in a hat and dress that are too big and she is going through a black purse that is on the floor in front of her.  She sits in the center of the bottom of the painting and faces the viewer's left.  A pair of high heels lies on the floor in front of the purse.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow at the Big Horn Galleries, Aspen, Colorado, August 17, 1994.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Reunion
creator: Hessing, Valjean McCarty
subject: Choctaw
description: A painting of two women, two young girls and a toddler.  In the foreground an older woman is seated on a tree stump, she is reaching out to the oldest girl who is reaching out to her as they greet each other.  Behind the oldest girl is one who is slightly younger, she has her right hand up close to her mouth as she smiles.  A young woman stands behind the girls.  She has a toddler on her back in a blanket that is tied around her.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow at The Five Civilized Tribes Museum's "1981 Master Art Show," Muskogee, OK - where it won the second place award - September 20, 1981. Taped to dust cover (removed and placed in artist file):  Attach to entry; Artist:  Valjean McCarty Hessing; Title: "Reunion"; Medium:  Gouache; Artist's Tribe:  Choctaw; 100% Strathmore rag board.  On top of entry form:  2nd Place Oct. 15, 1981 five Civilized Tribe Master Show, Muskogee.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Night Opening Her Cloak
creator: Harjo, Benjamin, Jr.
subject: Seminole; Shawnee
description: A round painting of a woman in a Seminole style top and a long skirt as she pulls back what appears to be the night curtain (covered with stars) to reveal the day (viewer's left).  The woman faces the viewer's right and looks over her right shoulder as she pulls back the curtain with her right hand.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow from the Indian Paintbrush Gallery, Siloam Springs, Arkansas, September 3, 1991.  In addition to this painting the Zarrows purchased three Helen Hardin etchings.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

description: A painting of Venice which includes the Grand Canal with St. Mark's Piazza (background), Doges Palace and Daniell Hotel (foreground).
provenance: Purchased by Mr. And Mrs. Jack Zarrow from Loris Vendramin in St. Mark's Square, Venice, Italy, September 19, 1992. title: Slipping
creator: Tiger, Jerome
subject: Creek; Seminole
description: A painting of a young boy with a garden rake over his right shoulder.  His head is turned to the viewer's right, his body slightly so.  On his head he has a fedora style hat with a feather stuck in it.  His only articles of clothing are a pair of slightly too large pants (in danger of falling down) and some shoes.  His left hand behind his back is tugging at the back of the pants.  His right hand holds the rake on his shoulder.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow from Linda Warren and her son, Anthony warren, in Oklahoma City, OK, May 30, 1996. On dust cover:  This painting appears on page of the "Life and Art of Jerome Tiger" book by Peggy Tiger and Molly Babcock.  On May 30, 1996 Maxine and Jack Zarrow purchased this from Linda Warren and her son, Anthony Warren.  Anthony's Grandmother, Eloise Hall Warren, bought this painting from the Tiger family in 1966 or 1967.  Eloise Warren grew up in Eufaula, and spent her adult life in Oklahoma City.  Cleve and Linda Warren 2524 N.W. 55th Place, Oklahoma City, OK.  (405) 538-2395  (405) 842-6307.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Plains Indian dancers
creator: Beaver, Fred
subject: Creek
description: A painting, done on a tan background, of two Indian dancers dressed in pow-wow Fancy War Dance costumes: two feathered bustles (one at the top of back and one at the bottom of the back), roach headdress with feathers, breechclout with beaded belt, beaded cuffs, beaded head band and collar, beaded moccasins, and jingle bell bands just below the knees.  The dancers face each other and hold dance fans in their left hands and sticks in their right hands.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow from Fred Beaver at his home in Checotah, OK, March 6, 1980.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Listening to the Old Man
creator: Henson, Brooks
subject: Cherokee
description: A painting of a man and a boy sitting on a red blanket on the ground in the woods.  They face each other and the man has his left hand extended toward the boy.  The boy appears to listen intently.  He is wearing a blue and white striped shirt and brown pants.  The man is wearing fringed buckskin clothing and a red turban with two feathers attached.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow at The Art Market, Tulsa, OK, July 14, 1991. On backing:  Listening to the Old Man, $135.00.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Warrior of the Plains
creator: Gray, Gina
subject: Osage
description: A painting of a 3/4 length portrait of an Indian man.  He faces the viewer and is wrapped in a blanket that is black on his left side and red on his right side.  It has a blue star design on the black side.  On his head he wears a headdress with a single feather and around his neck he wears a pipe bone choker.  On the left side his face has four red stripes painted on it from his forehead to his chin.  He holds a feather decorated shield in his right hand.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow at the Indian Paintbrush Gallery, Siloam Springs, Arkansas, August 30, 1991. On dust cover:  1991 "Warrior of the Plains"  watercolor  Gina Gray; Purchased from Indian Paintbrush, Siloam Springs, AR $365.

title: William Pollack, Pawnee Veteran of San Juan Hill
creator: Echohawk, Brummett
subject: Pawnee
description: A head and shoulder portrait of a mustached man in a military uniform (Army uniform of 1898).  He faces the viewer's left.  He wears a gray wide brimmed hat with crossed sabers pinned to the side of the crown.  The uniform shirt is gray with the exception of a brown stand up collar.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow from Brummett Echohawk, Tulsa, OK, June 19, 1996.  One of nine paintings purchased from Echohawk at this time. On tape on frame:  "7 1/2 X 9 1/2, oil; William Pollock, "Pawnee Veteran of San Juan Hill;" Raised American Flag - Spanish American War.  Brummett Echohawk 19 June 1996. On stretcher:  "William Pollock, Pawnee Veteran of San Juan Hill" oil, June 1996.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Rainbow Dances With The Pueblos
creator: Padilla, Fernando, Jr.
subject: Navajo; San Felipe
description: A painting of a Pueblo building with people seated on the upper roofs.  There are corn, watermelon, bean, and pepper plants growing in the foreground and a rainbow god in the sky above the Pueblo.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow at The Art Market, Tulsa, OK, March 7, 1991. On dust cover:  "Rainbow Dances With The Pueblos" by Fernando Padilla 1991.  Also:  Property of Maxine and Jack Zarrow, Purchased 3/7/91  Art Market, Tulsa, OK  $550.00.

title: Abstract Apartment Patterns
creator: Kirze, Yehiel
description: An abstract painting of irregular squares and black lines that give the appearance of windows.  Colors:  blue, pink, red, white, gold/cream with black lines and circles.
provenance: This painting was purchased from the artist by Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Forman in Hifa, Israel at the artists studio.  They were visiting Mr. Forman's niece, Sara and her husband Jacob Solomon who lived in Israel.  Mr. and Mrs. Solomon took them to visit the artist and see his work.   Maxine Forman Zarrow inherited the painting from her parents.  For information on Yehiel Kirze see:  "Art In Israel" by Ron Shechori, Schocken Books, New York, 1976, pages 23 and 38
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Eagle Chief, Chief of the Pawnees
creator: Echohawk, Brummett
subject: Pawnee
description: A waist up portrait of a Pawnee man who faces the viewer.  He wears a pillbox shaped hat with a beak like extension in the front (points toward the viewer's right), silver earrings (ring with 3 dangles), a bear claw and beads collar with decorated trailers, and brass armbands.  He holds a brass headed tomahawk in front of him with his right hand on the shaft and his left hand and forearm supporting the head.  A peace medal hangs on his chest below the bear claw collar.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow from Brummett Echohawk, Tulsa, Oklahoma, June 19, 1996.  One of nine paintings purchased from Echohawk at this time. On dust cover:  Brummett Echohawk (signature), 19 June 1996  Eagle Chief, Grand Chief of the Pawnees; tempera, 5" X 7".

title: Man Chief, Grand Chief of the Pawnees
creator: Echohawk, Brummett
subject: Pawnee
description: A painting of a Pawnee man standing facing the viewer's right.  He is wearing a feathered headdress with a long feathered trailer hanging down his back.  His clothing consists of a red shirt, beaded buckskin pants, and high topped bead decorated boot style moccasins.  His right arm hangs down at his side.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow from Brummett Echohawk, Tulsa, Oklahoma, June 19, 1996.  One of nine paintings by Echohawk purchased at this time. On dust cover:  Brummett Echohawk (signature; tempera painting "Man Chief," Peta Lesharo - Pawnee Band Pechawrat (1 of four bands) Last Grand Chief of the Pawnee Indians, Lived in 1860s & 1870s.

title: Indian still life
creator: Buster, Garnet
description: A still life printing of a ceramic "wedding" vase (red color, viewer's right) and a bowl (black color, viewer's left).  A multi-colored string of glass beads is wrapped around the right (viewer's) neck of the "wedding" vase and hangs across and off of the table.  A silver squash blossom necklace is draped in the bowl and hangs off of the table.  Behind the pots, on either side, are ears of corn and two eagle feathers - quill up.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow from Garnet Buster at The country Osage Art Exhibit and Sale, Pawhuska, Oklahoma, June 20, 1981.  One of four works of art purchased at this exhibition. Taped to dust cover (now in artist's file):  6/20/1981, Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow; Indian Still Life by garnet Buster; 12 X 24; watercolor; $850.00.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Stickball players
creator: Beaver, Fred
subject: Creek
description: A painting of two Indian men facing each other with four stickball sticks in their hands.  They are wearing roach headdresses, fringed necklaces, and red and blue breechclouts.  The man on the viewers right has a decoration attached to his lower back (looks like a tail).  There is red paint across their eyes and three painted stripes on each of their forearms, thighs, and lower legs.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow from Fred Beaver at his home in Checotah, Oklahoma, May 6, 1980.  One of several that the Zarrows purchased at this time. On dust cover:  Fred Beaver died Aug. 19, 1980.

creator: Franklin, John
description: A drawing of a seated woman with her hair pulled back (in a bun).  She holds one end of a striped shawl in her right hand at her waist and the other end in her left hand up close to her left ear.  She faces slightly to the viewer's right.
provenance: Purchased by Maxine Zarrow from John Franklin at his studio, Taos, New Mexico, June 2, 1995.

title: Working Hard
creator: Little Thunder, Merlin
subject: Southern Cheyenne
description: A painting of a man seated on the ground with his back against a tree stump.  He is wearing a cowboy hat with a feather in the hatband, a red neck scarf, a blue and red shirt, brown pants, and cowboy boots.  He faces the viewer�s right.  Behind him, also leaning against the stump, is an axe and sitting on the stump one half of a watermelon with a knife stuck in it.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow at The Art Market, Tulsa, Oklahoma, some time after 1991.

title: Untitled (Fancy war dancer)
creator: Blue Eagle, Acee
subject: Creek; Pawnee
description: A hand-painted print of a pow-wow fancy war dancer wearing a roach headdress with three feathers, a lower back bustle, and feathers on his upper arms.  In addition he wears a beaded collar, beaded gantlets, beaded wrist and ankle bands, a breechlout, and beaded moccasins.  The upper half of his face is painted red and his hair is braided and wrapped with fur.  He holds a fan in his right hand and a flute in his left hand.
provenance: Unknown

title: Untitled (Two women carrying water)
creator: Atencio, Gilbert Benjamin
subject: San Ildefonso
description: A painting of two Pueblo women with large ceramic jars by a water source.  One of the women (in foreground, facing viewer's left) is approaching the water and holds a jar in her hands in front of her.  The other woman (in the middle ground, facing viewer's right) is leaving the water source with her jar balanced on her head.  Both women are dressed in the traditional hand-woven one-shoulder dress, small cape, and dance boots.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow at the Indian Paintbrush Gallery, Siloam Springs, Arkansas, November 21, 1980.

title: Courting with flute ceremony
creator: Beaver, Fred
subject: Creek
description: A painting of a woman seated under a tree (viewer's right) as she stirs a pot.  She is on the far side of a campfire.  Standing facing her (on the viewer's left) is a man playing a flute.  He is dressed in a red breechclout with a bead-decorated waistband and moccasins.  Around his neck is a beaded choker whose design matches the waistband and moccasins.  In his hair he wears a feather ornament.  A river runs beside this scene and a setting sun (or moon) is in the background.  The scenery is painted in blacks and grays.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow from Fred Beaver at his home in Checotah, Oklahoma, March 6, 1980.  One of several the Zarrows purchased at this time. This painting was exhibited at the Gilcrease Museum's "McCombs/Beaver Memorial Exhibition, Tulsa, OK, March 7 - April 19, 1981.On dust cover:  Fred Beaver (1911 - 1980; Courting Flute Ceremony; gouache; 1973; Collection:  Maxine and Jack Zarrow.

title: Deer and Fawn
creator: Nailor, Gerald
subject: Navajo
description: A painting of a deer (facing viewer's left) with her ears laid back.  In front of her and facing her is a fawn (facing viewer's right).  The fawn's head over laps the deer's left shoulder.  Behind the two deer are stylized plants and bushes and there is a Navajo Yei symbol in the sky.  The painting is done in tones of brown and tan.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow from Robert F. Nichols of Santa Fe, New Mexico, March 26, 1992.  This painting was one of four purchased.  The others were by:  Pablita Velarde, Gene Kloss, and Geronima Montoya.

title: Young shepherd and pet goats
creator: Begay, Harrison
subject: Navajo
description: A painting of a young Navajo boy dressed in a red shirt and light blue pants as he moves to the viewer's right.  He has a turquoise and sliver pin at the neck of his shirt, a turquoise and sliver belt buckle, and a turquoise and silver button on his Apache style moccasins.  In his right hand he holds a coil of rope and in his left the other end of the rope make into a throwing loop.  Two young kids gambol in front of him and behind him.  There is rainbow Yei symbol in the sky over their heads.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow from the Indian Paintbrush Gallery, Siloam Springs, Arkansas, November, 25, 1980.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

subject: Cherokee

subject: Jemez

subject: Quapaw; Shawnee; Cherokee

title: Stomp Dance
creator: Jacob, Murv
subject: Cherokee

Blumenschein (1874-1960) Left to his daughter, Helen Blumenschein (1909 � 1989) Her estate left to cousin � Santa Fe resident.  Hansen Gallery acquired the painting 1980.

title: Living Memories of a Distant Past
creator: Rutledge, Cathy
subject: Choctaw; Cherokee
description: A painting of a gray haired man sitting on a log  stool (viewer's left of painting and facing viewer's right) as he dreams of a stickball game (picture of game in viewer's upper right).  He is wearing a wide brimmed hat, a white shirt and black pants.  The man's right hand rests on his right thigh and grasps the handle of a stickball stick.  His left hand rests on his left knee and holds a string that is attached to a stickball stick.  Several more such sticks are in a pile at his feet and it appears he has been making them.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow at  the Five Civilized Tribes Museum's Annual Art Exhibition,  Muskogee, Oklahoma, October 19, 1980. Glued to dust cover:  !. Attach to entry: Artist:  Cathy Rutledge; Title:  "living Memories of a  Distant Past"; Medium:  oil; Price:  $450.00;  Artist's Tribe:  Choctaw.  Exhibition Label (glued to dust cover):  "Living Memories of a Distant Past" by Cathy Rutledge  (Choctaw); oil; $450; Honorable Mention (written in ink).  Stapled to back of frame:  yellow Honorable Mention ribbon (removed to artist file).
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Deerslayer's Dream
creator: Hardin, Helen
subject: Santa Clara
description: A somewhat abstract etching of a man (almost stick figure) with two shadow images behind him.  He is on the viewer's left and faces the viewer.  To his left and behind him are petroglyph images of deer - five orange colored, three brown colored, and four that are outlines.  The man holds a bow in his left hand and two arrows in his right.  Behind the man is a series of circles and a horizontal zig-zag line that goes from one edge of the etching to the other.
provenance: :  Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow at the Indian Paintbrush Gallery, Siloam Springs, Arkansas, September 3, 1991. Print Documentation (see artist file):  Printed 3/6/81 at El Cerro Graphics, Los Lunes, NM; William Boyson and Ricardo Ximenes printers.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Women at San Juan, Women at the Spring
creator: Montoya, Geronima/Potsunu
subject: San Juan
description: A painting of seven Pueblo women getting water from a spring.  They are all dressed in the traditional one-shoulder dress (although the fabrics vary) with a blouse under it and a long scarf/cape over their heads and hanging down almost to the hem of their dresses.  Three of the women (viewer's left) have filled their ceramic jars and are carrying them on their heads as they head home (face viewer's left).  Behind the spring are two women who are waiting to fill their jars.  To the viewer's right of the spring are two women - one kneeling and filling a jar and another standing behind her watching.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow from Robert F. Nichols, Santa Fe, New Mexico, March 26, 1992.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Untitled (Man with blue hat)
creator: Biggoose, Marcellus "Mars"
subject: Ponca
description: A painting of the head and shoulders of a man with long black hair (facing viewer's left) wearing a wide brimmed, smooth crowned blue hat.  The hat has a beaded band with a feather attached.  The man has a mauve colored blanket around his shoulders and his image stops there (upper half of the painting).  A line curves downward from the front edge of his blanket and circles to the viewer's right.  At this point the line changes to a brown band that seems to move away from the viewer.  Two blanket wrapped figures (back to viewer) stand on the brown band as though waking down a trail.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow, where, when, how, and price not available.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Answer
creator: Anderson, Troy
subject: Cherokee
description: A painting of seven blanket wrapped figures (viewer's left) - three in foreground, two behind them, and two in the distance - in a snowstorm.  In the sky in front of a moon (viewer's right) is a spirit like image of a man holding a feather in his right hand.  He appears to be speaking.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow at the Five Civilized Tribes Museum, Troy Anderson One-man Show, Muskogee, Oklahoma, April 13, 1980.  This is one of nineteen paintings by Troy Anderson that the Zarrows purchased at this time.

title: Bountiful Mother
creator: Hardin, Helen
subject: Santa Clara
description: An etching of a figure shaped like an ear of corn wearing an elaborate tablita (headdress) with corn painted on it.  The face is painted like a Pueblo ceremonial mask and in place of a husk the figure wears (like a cape) a hand-woven and embroidered blanket.  The figure also wears high-topped dance boots.  In the background is an embossed image of a Pueblo.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow at the Indian Paintbrush Gallery, Siloam Springs, Arkansas, September 3, 1991.  Print Documentation (see artist file):  This etching is dated 5/18/80.  It was printed by El Cerro Graphics, Richard C. Ximenes, printer, Las Lunas, NM.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Reflecting
creator: Shoemaker, Ben Adair
subject: Quapaw; Shawnee; Cherokee
description: A painting of seven evenly spaced figures walking toward the viewer's right around the edge of a pond with green hills and clouds in the background.  Their images are reflected in the pond.  These figures appear to be both men and women.  Their clothing is all brown and their hair is gray.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow at the Cherokee National Museum's "Trail of Tears" Show and Sale, Tahlequah, Oklahoma, June 19, 1981.  This painting won a 2nd place award at this exhibition.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Plains medicine man
creator: Beaver, Fred
subject: Creek
description: A painting of two men sitting in front of a teepee.  The man on the viewer's right is dressed in a "war" bonnet and beaded buckskin clothing and is smoking a ceremonial pipe.  The man on the viewer's left is dressed in a breechclout and moccasins and is beating a drum.  There is a campfire in the foreground and two horses are ground tied behind and to the left of the teepees.  There are mesas and a big sun in the background.
provenance: :  Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow from Fred Beaver at his home in Checotah, Oklahoma, May 6, 1980.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Four Dancers
creator: Pena, Tonita/Quah Ah
subject: San Ildefonso
description: A painting of three Pueblo dancers (facing viewer's right) and a drummer (facing viewer's left).  The furthest left dancer is a female holding a bow and arrows in her left hand and Spruce boughs in her right as she sings.  In front of her is a female dressed in the traditional white hand-woven sleeveless dress ceremonial dress with a rain sash and dance boots.  She holds feathers in her right hand that is raised up to her shoulder.  In front of her is a man dressed in an Pueblo eagle costume.  Facing the dancers is a man dressed in buckskin clothing, wearing a "war" bonnet who is beating a drum.  In the lower right corner of the painting is a rain and lighting symbol.
provenance: PROVENIENCE:  Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow from Dewey Galleries, Santa Fe, New Mexico, September 18, 1991.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Camouflage (printed on front of painting)
creator: Joshua, Lee
subject: Creek; Seminole
description: A painting of an Indian hunter kneeling on his right knee in some tall grass.  He faces the viewer and looks to the viewer's left,  He has a bow and arrows in a quiver on his back.  An animal skin (buffalo hide?) hangs down around his elbows and across his back.  The title "Camouflage" in printed at the bottom of the painting.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow from the artist, either at the Zarrows home or from the artist's truck at the Five Civilized Tribes' parking lot, Muskogee, Oklahoma, ca. 1980.

title: Pause for thought
creator: Anderson, Troy
subject: Cherokee
description: A painting of a wooded snow scene with seven figures wrapped in blankets on the left side.  There are two round objects in the sky (sun and moon?).  The figure in the foreground faces the viewer's right and has a staff in his right hand.  The other figures have their backs to the viewer.  This is a painting of people on the Cherokee's Trail of Tears.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow at the Five Civilized Tribes Museum's Troy Anderson One-man Show, Muskogee, Oklahoma, April 3, 1980.  This painting was one of nineteen paintings by Troy Anderson that the Zarrows purchased at this time. On dust cover:  Pause for Thought.

title: Ancient Buffalo Song
creator: Hood, Larry
subject: Comanche
description: A painting of a Plains Indian warrior (facing the viewer) wearing a buffalo headdress.  He is wearing long dangle earrings and is wrapped in a multi-colored blanket.  He is holding a shield with four anthropomorphic figures painted on it.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow from Wes Gan at Native American Art, Tulsa, Oklahoma, 1992.  On dust cover:  "Ancient Buffalo song" . Oct. 92; Artist:  Larry Hood (Comanche) from artist to Wes Gan 323 S. Main, Tulsa, OK 74107  1-918-584-5792.

title: The Judge - It's Indian Law
creator: Herrera, Joe
subject: Cochiti
description: A geometric abstract painting of a Kachina face and hands (facing viewer).  The right hand holds a rattle and the left hand a staff with two feathers at the top.  The painting is done in multi-colors and then sprayed with multi-colored dots.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow though correspondence with James Conlon, Albuquerque, New Mexico, November, 5, 1991. Glued to dust cover:  11/11/91 Joe H. Herrera, Cochiti Pueblo, NM; 20" X 26"  casein on paper, sprayed and brush application - Depiction of Kachina mask executed in Herrera's geometric style.  Also:  The Judge; Its Indian Law,  Joe Herrera (signature)  1989.

title: Summer camp
creator: Bales, Jean
subject: Iowa
description: A painting of a Plains Indian camp with two teepees and multiple activities.  It contains twelve women, eight men, three young girls, six young boys, one baby, five horses, two foals, five white dogs, and five white puppies.  The activities include, hanging meat to dry, teaching arrow making, gathering wood, cooking, tending horses, a hunter delivering meat, and child tending.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow at The Art Market, Tulsa, OK, from the Halsey Collection, January 1, 1992.  On dust cover:  Acquired from Halsey Collection  1/92; Gallup Ceremonial Award (not confirmed!!!)  Taped to dust cover:  Summer Camp by Jean Bales won 1st place at Heard Museum rec's purple ribbon in 1977 at Phoenix, Ariz.  Acquired from Jim and Menissa (Crumbo) Halsey Collection 1-92.  Also:  Purple Ribbon; Heard Museum Arts and Crafts Exhibit 1977; Name: Jane E. Bales; Owner: "Summer Camp"; Class:  1st Place; Date:  77; Judge:  Heard Museum (obviously someone filled in the information the way they wanted, not what was called for).
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

creator: Moline, Bob
subject: Comanche
description: A profile portrait of a man (facing viewer's right) with long brown hair wearing a bead decorated fur brow band that has a vertical feather at the back.  He is wearing a sleeveless blue shirt.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow at Trails West Gallery, Scottsdale, Arizona.  The Zarrows also purchased "Red Eagle" by Bob Moline. On dust cover:  #14279 "Straight Dancer"  1980.  On business card:  Property of Mr. and Mrs. Jack  Zarrow 6.23.80.

title: untitled - Indian man on horse
creator: Seltzer, Steve
description: A painting of an Indian sitting on a horse which is done in the style of Olaf C. Seltzer (the artist's grandfather).  The Indian and the horse face the viewer's right.  The Indian holds a bow case across his lap and has a shield on his left arm.  He is wearing blue leggings and is sitting in an Indian style saddle with a hide draped over it.  The horse is a brown and white paint with two feathers tied to his forelock.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow from the artist at Joan Stauffer's home, Tulsa, OK, 1979. On dust cover:  Property of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow; W S (Steve) Seltzer; June 1979.

title: Dance
creator: Anderson, Troy
subject: Cherokee
description: A painting done on gray mat board of the back view of a hoop dancer.  He wears a roach headdress, upper and lower back bustles, a black breechclout, �jingle� bells and long hair (goat hair) calf bands, and beaded moccasins.  He image is painted in front of a blue circle and appears to be dancing with two red hoops - one circles his upper body and one circles his lower body.  The title, "Dance," is written at the bottom edge of the painting.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow at the Five Civilized Tribes Museum's Troy Anderson One-man Show, Muskogee, Oklahoma, April 13, 1980.  This was one of nineteen paintings by Troy Anderson that the Zarrows purchased at this time.

creator: Anderson, Troy
subject: Cherokee
description: An airbrush painting of a peace pipe silhouette with four feathers attached - two at each end of the pipe.  It slants diagonally across the paper from the upper left to the lower right with the mouthpiece and stem at the top.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow at the Five Civilized tribes Museum's Troy Anderson One-man Show, Muskogee, Oklahoma, April 13, 1980. title: Four spirits
creator: Anderson, Troy
subject: Cherokee
description: A painting done on brown mat board of the faces of four men with long black hair arranged one above the other and superimposed over a big brown circle and three smaller blue circles.  The men's hair appears to be blowing to the viewer's right.  The brown circle was created by air brushing with white paint and masking out the circle.  The title, "Four Spirits," is written at the lower edge of the painting.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow at the Five Civilized Tribes museum's Troy Anderson One-man Show, Muskogee, Oklahoma, April 13, 1980.  This was one of nineteen paintings purchased by the Zarrows at this time.

title: Wind Blown
creator: Hood, Larry
subject: Comanche
description: A painting of an image of an Indian man (facing the viewer).  He is wrapped in a red and blue blanket with a gold and white stripe separating the two colors.  A bow and a quiver full of arrows hang across his front.  a strong wind appears to be blowing from the viewer's left to the right.  The man has a white star painted on his right cheek and a band of red and white painted from his forehead to his chin on the left side of his face.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow from Wes Gan at Native American Art, Tulsa, Oklahoma, October 13, 1991.

creator: Garza, Manuel
description: A painting of a stream with three teepees.  The stream runs across the foreground and then into the middle ground on the viewer's right. title: Osage Child Naming Ceremony
creator: Woodring, Carl/WA-SA-BA Shinga
subject: Osage
description: A painting of a man and a woman with a baby in a cradleboard.  The man, who faces the viewer and looks to the viewer's right, is dressed in the traditional Osage costume - pillbox shaped fur hat with beading and feathers, a breechclout with bead decorated fringed buckskin pants, and beaded moccasins.  He holds a string of beads in his left hand and a drawstring bag in his right hand.  The woman (on the viewer's left and facing the man on her left) has a shawl tied around her waist and is wearing beaded high-topped moccasins and holds a baby in a cradleboard.  There are paintings of buffalo in each corner.  The buffalo are drawn with corn and bean plants on their backs.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow through correspondence with Tom Woodard at Woodard's Native American Art, Santa Fe, New Mexico, December 5, 1992.  Glued to dust cover:  Artist:  Carl Woodring; Address:  1608 So. College; Town:  Tulsa, OK; Title:  Osage Child Naming Ceremony; Price:  $25.00.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

creator: Lomakema, Milland
subject: Hopi

In their right hands they hold a rattle and in their left hands a bow.  They face the viewer's right.

title: Fancy dancer
creator: Belindo, Dennis (Aun-So-Te)
subject: Kiowa; Navajo
description: A painting on tan mat board of a pow-wow fancy war dancer.  He faces the viewer's right and is wearing a roach headdress, upper and lower back bustles, a red breechclout with a wide beaded waist band, black tights (or his legs are painted black), calf bands of "jingle bells", and beaded moccasins.  In his right hand he holds a feather fan and in his left a blue stick.  He is bent over as he lifts his left leg and reaches forward with his right hand.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow at The Art Market, Tulsa, Oklahoma, March 29, 1992.  On dust cover:  "Fancy Dancer"; tempera; 15" x  10.5"; museum mounted 3-18-92.

title: The Masked Gods Revenge on Koshares
creator: Naha, Raymond
subject: Hopi
description: A painting on gray mat board of four men dressed as Kachinas chasing three men dressed as Koshares.  There is a Kiva in the background with a Koshare sticking his head out and behind that a Pueblo.  This scene takes place in the Pueblo's plaza area.  One Koshare is being hit with a thrown watermelon, another is being chased with snake, and another is being held down on the ground and his headdress has been pulled off by a Kokapeli Mana Kachina.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow at Dewey Gallery, Santa Fe, New Mexico, February 13, 1992.  Stickers on backing:  #1  Title:  The Masked Gods Revenge on Koshares;  Artist:  Raymond Naha Hopi  1960; Medium:  watercolor; Size:  32" X 40";  Number: A 1602-001.  #2  Naha Raymond; "Masked Gods Revenge on Koshares;  Number: 76; watercolor; 32" X 40".
