title: Arapahoes War Dancers
creator: Sweezy, Carl
subject: Arapaho
description: A painting of six dancers and three drummers.  The three drummers sit in a circle around a large drum in the center of the painting (one on each side and one at the back of the drum).  In their left hands they hold a feather fan and in their right hands (raised to strike the drum) a drumstick.  There are three dancers in a row on each side of the drummers.  They are wearing roach headdresses, feathered upper arm bands, lower back feather bustles, bands of "jingle Bells" on their calves, breechclouts, and beaded moccasins. They are in various positions as they dance.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow at the Oklahoma Indian Art Gallery, Oklahoma City, Oklahoma, July 21, 1992. Note found with painting:  Artist:  Carl Sweezy;  title:  "Arapahoe War Dancers";  Medium:  oil on canvas; Circa:  Early 1930's.      The canvas used for this painting is off an old window shade.  "The Arapahoe Way", written by Althea Bass, is a book on the life story of Carl Sweezy.  Ms. Bass lived in Norman, Oklahoma until the age of 93, at this time she sold her entire estate and moved to Washington D.C. to live with her only son.  "Arapahoe War Dancers", was in her collection.  Approximately eight (8) years ago this piece was purchased by the Oklahoma Indian Art Gallery and sold to Mr. Robb Moore.  Mr. Moore held this piece in his collection approximately four (4) years and decided to place it on the market with a number of other pieces.  This painting was brought to Oklahoma Indian Art Gallery for consignment and remained in inventory until purchased by Jack Zarrow in 1992.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: untitled - dancer
creator: Saul, C. Terry
subject: Choctaw; Chickasaw

title: Kassa
creator: Gutierrez, Geraldine
subject: Santa Clara; San Ildefonso
description: A painting of an adult Kassa (aka Koshare) clown (viewer's left) dancing and reaching toward a Kassa symbol in the sky.  His body is painted in the traditional black and white stripes and wears the traditional hand-woven breechclout.  He faces the viewer's right.  In front of him - on the viewer's right is a ceramic jar with a young Kassa straddling it.  In front of the jar is a basket full of corn.  There are geometric designs below the figures and in the upper left corner.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow from Robert F. Nichols, Santa Fe, New Mexico, February 1, 1994.  On dust cover:  Artist:  Geraldine Gutierrez - San Ildefonso Pueblo (her uncle Gilbert Atencio, painter); "Kassa"  1993 - watercolor; 9 1/2 X 14 1/4; Purchased from Robert F. Nichols - Santa Fe, NM, Feb 1, 1994 #93.25  840; Picture 93.07 B #19.

title: untitled - three Indians on horses
creator: Dick, Cecil
subject: Cherokee
description: A painting of three Plains Indians on horses riding at a canter slightly toward the viewer's left.  The horse on the viewer's right is green, the middle horse is a gray and white paint and the one on the left is olive colored.  The rider on the viewer's right is wearing a "war" bonnet and has a shield painted with a wolf head fastened to his left arm.  The center rider holds a shield painted with a buffalo head on his left arm and a feather decorated staff in his right hand.  The rider on the left holds a bow in the air with his right hand.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow at The Art Market, Tulsa, Oklahoma, December 18, 1992.  On dust cover:  Untitled; tempera; about 1939;  Cecil Dick, artist Cherokee Died 1992; 13 X 19. Note in artist's file:  This Cecil Dick painting was part of an Albuquerque collection that was sold in 1992.  There was also an Alan Houser and an Archie Blackowl painting in the collection.   The Houser and the Blackowl were dated '39 and '40.  The collectors left written information that the three paintings were purchased at the Santa Fe Indian - Dunn school in 1939 and 1940.  They indicated that this piece was 1939.  Linda Greever 1/93  (The Art Market, Tulsa, OK)  Cecil Dick, Artist Cherokee 13" X 19" untitled, circa 1939, tempera Artist died in 1992  Property of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow 2660 S. Birmingham Pl., Tulsa, Okla.

creator: Jones, Ruthe Blalock/Chu-Lun-Dit
subject: Deleware; Shawnee; Peoria

title: Tesuque Snake Dancer
creator: Vigil Thomas/Pan Yo Pin
subject: Tesuque
description: A painting of a Pueblo dancer facing the viewer's left.  His lower face is painted black, his forearms and hands are painted blue and his upper body and lower legs are painted brown with white lighting designs (zig-zag).  He is wearing an orange kilt with a snake painted on it and an animal skin hangs down the back of the kilt.  He holds a rattle in his right hand and two feathers in his left hand.  There is a black and yellow snake coiled in front of him.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow by phone from Gallery 10, Inc., Scottsdale, Arizona, January 13, 1991.  This painting was one of eleven paintings purchased at this time from Gallery 10. Data from Gallery 10:  Ex. John Hill Collection, Phoenix, AZ.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Pueblo Dancer
creator: Roybal, Jose D.
subject: San Ildefonso
description: A painting of a Pueblo dancer facing the viewer's right.  His upper body and lower legs are painted blue and he is dressed in a white hand-woven embroidered kilt that is tied up with a rain sash.  An animal skin (fox) hangs down the back of the kilt.  He holds a rattle in his right hand and a Spruce bough in his left hand.  His right leg is bent at the knee and the foot raised as he dances.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow by phone from Gallery 10, Inc., Scottsdale, Arizona, January 13, 1991.  This painting was one of eleven paintings purchased at this time from Gallery 10.  Data from Gallery 10:  EX. Roswell Coll., an extensive and well documented collection of Native American paintings.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Longhair Kachina
creator: Poseyesva, Raymond John
subject: Hopi
description: A painting of a masked Pueblo man who faces the viewer while he dances.  His upper body is painted yellow and black and his lower legs are yellow.   He wears a white hand-woven embroidered kilt that is held up with a rain sash.  In addition he wears hand-made hard-soled boots and a "jingle" bell band around his left calf.  An animal skin hangs down the back of the kilt (tail is visible below the hem of the kilt).  He holds a rattle in his right hand and a Spruce branch in his left hand.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. jack Zarrow by phone from Gallery 10, Inc., Scottsdale, Arizona, April 17, 1992.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Spiritual World
creator: Herrera, Joe
subject: Cochiti
description: A painting of various petroglyph, Kachina, plant and animal figures.  There are nine Kachina figures, seventeen petroglyph images, four animals, and three plants.  They are over sprayed with multi-colored dots.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow from Dewey Gallery, Santa Fe, New Mexico, September 18, 1991.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Anasazi Puberty Ceremony
creator: Herrera, Joe
subject: Cochiti
description: A stylized painting of a young woman and four men wearing ceremonial costumes (priests).  The young woman (lower center of the painting) is lying on her back on a rug - head to the viewer's right.  There are two of the "priests" crouched down - one behind the other - at her head and two crouched down at her feet (also one behind the other).  The "priests" wear elaborate headdresses and either kilts or breechclouts.  The two closest to the young woman (head and foot) hold decorated staffs in their left hands and rattles in their right hands.   The "priest" on the viewer's far right holds a bow in his right hand and a tree branch in his left.  The "priest on the viewer's far left holds a tomahawk in his right hand and two feathers in his left hand.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow from Dewey Gallery, Santa Fe, New Mexico, September 18, 1991.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Cheyenne Spirit
creator: Tiger, Johnny, Jr.
subject: Creek; Seminole
description: A portrait of an Indian man (head and shoulders) who is facing the viewer.  He has two feathers attached to a medallion on the right side of his head - feathers hang down - and he wears a hare bone choker at his throat.  There is a red circle to his left and his head is in the center of two circles - red and yellow.  Above him is the outline of a face (facing upward) that gives the effect of a mountain range.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow from Johnny Tiger, Muskogee, Oklahoma, March 11, 1981.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Mudhead
creator: Velarde, Pablita/Tse Tsan
subject: Santa Clara
description: A painting of a Mudhead Kachina who appears to be going up some steps.  His body faces the viewer's right and his head is turned toward the viewer.   In addition to the Mudhead mask he wears a black kilt, black wristbands, and hard-soled dance boots.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. jack Zarrow from Robert F. Nichols, Santa Fe, New Mexico, March 26, 1992. One of four paintings purchased at this time.  The others were by G. Kloss, G. Nailor, and Geronima Montoya. On 2 labels glued to dust cover (removed to artist's file):  1.  Artist:  Velarde, Pablita; Indian Name (blank); title of Painting:  Mudhead; Exhibitor:  DLR; Class: IV; Tribe:  Santa Clara; Price: (missing); Address:  Scottsdale. (label partially destroyed by insects) 2.  Pablita Velarde TSE TSAN (golden Dawn); Born:  September 19, 1918 Santa Clara Pueblo, New Mexico; Awards:  1946 - 1965  DAM, ITIC, MNM, NMSF, PAC, and one Grand Award; Collections:  Many public and private.

title: When Meat Was Scarce
creator: Wall, Ralph
description: A painting of a snowy winter scene with three riders crossing a frozen stream.  Two of the riders are wearing buffalo headdresses and all three are wrapped in buffalo hides.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow from the artist through correspondence, July 30, 1981.  On the back of painting, in artist's handwriting "When Meat Was Scarce"; 1980, Ralph Wall. Ralph Wall produced reproductions of his paintings and gave the Zarrows a copy of the reproduction - A/P3 which is stored in drawer #9 of the map cabinet in their stroage area.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Koshare Clown and Dancer
creator: Popovi Da/Tony Martinez
subject: San Ildefonso
description: A painting of a Koshare (Kachina clown) as he approaches a ceremonial dancer.  The clown faces the dancer (viewer's left) and reaches out toward him.  The dancer faces the viewer.  The clown is painted with the traditional black and white stripes and wears the traditional headdress.  The dancer's upper body and lower legs are painted gray and he wears a traditional white hand-woven embroidered kilt and a rain sash.  He holds a rattle in his right hand and some Spruce branches in his left.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow through correspondence with Gallery 10, Inc., Scottsdale, Arizona, January 13, 1991.  This painting was one of eleven paintings purchased at this time from Gallery 10. Data from Gallery 10, Inc.:  Acquired with Ray Dewey, Dewey Galleries, Santa Fe, New Mexico.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Untitled (Eagle dancer)
creator: Auchiah, James
subject: Kiowa
description: A painting of an eagle dancer who faces the viewer with his head turned to his right.  He wears a roach headdress, wing like feathers on his arms, a lower back bustle, a leather breast plate, a breechclout with a wide beaded belt, "jingle" bell calf bands and dance moccasins.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow at The Art Market, Tulsa, OK, April 10, 1991.

title: Fancy dancer
creator: Big Bow, Woodie
subject: Kiowa
description: a painting of a pow-wow fancy war dancer who faces the viewer's left.  He is dressed in a "war" bonnet, a lower back feather bustle, a red breechclout with a wide beaded belt, "jingle" bell bands around his calves, and dance moccasins with goat hair at the tops.  He has a decorated shield on his left arm.  He is doubled over as he raises his left leg in the dance.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow from Doris Littrell at the Oklahoma Indian Art Gallery, Oklahoma City, Oklahoma, July 24, 1992. Stamped on cardboard backing: Huffhines House, Wichita Falls, KS.

title: Ceremonial
creator: Asah, Spencer
subject: Kiowa
description: A painting of three figures - two men and a woman - involved in a ceremony.  The woman stands to the back (viewer's left) and faces slightly to her left (viewer's right).  She is wearing a beaded and fringed buckskin dress and has a red shawl over her right arm.  In front of her and to her left is a man kneeling on his left knee as he beats a drum.  He is dressed in a "war" bonnet, a red breechclout with a wide beaded belt, black beaded leggings and fully beaded moccasins.  Back of him is a man playing an Indian flute.  His hair is braided and wrapped with fur and he wears a fringed breechclout, shirt and red pants.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow from Doris Littrell at the Oklahoma Indian Art Gallery, Oklahoma City, Oklahoma, July 21, 1992.  The Zarrows purchased this painting by mail and phone conversations with Ms. Littrell.  On string tag:  Spencer Asah, "Ceremonial"  $3,800.00 . On dust cover:  From the collection of Mr. Boren, President of South Western College, Weatherford, OK (1940 - 1950).  Placed on consignment to Okla. Indian Art Gallery, 1991.  Purchased from Oklahoma Indian Art Gallery in 1992 (Doris Littrell) Oklahoma City.  Received from above in July 1992.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Untitled (Buffalo hunt accident)
creator: Yazz, Beatien
subject: Navajo
description: A painting of an Indian man on a horse as the horse jumps over a buffalo bull that has just been speared.  The buffalo is in the foreground with part of the spear in his right side.  The buffalo faces the viewer's left.  The man and horse are in the air over the buffalo.  They face the viewer's right.  The upper shaft of the spear is in the air under them.  It appears man and horse may not survive.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow from The Art Market, Tulsa, October 2, 1993.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Dance of the Mountain Gods
creator: Williams, David
subject: Kiowa; Tonkawa; Apache
description: A painting of four Apache dancers - three Gahn dancers and a clown.  The three Gahn dancers upper bodies are painted black with a white star front and back and white zigzags down their arms.  Their faces are also painted black and a red scarf covers the lower portion of their faces.  They wear three different headpieces, fringed buckskin kilts, "jingle" bell bands on their calves, and Apache dance boots.  They face three different directions as they dance and whirl around.  The clown's body is painted gray with a bull�s eye in the center of his back.  He wears a potato sack kilt with a cowbell at the back and Apache boots.  His head is covered with a sack mask.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow, ca. 4/91, no additional records available.  On dust cover:  "Dance of the Mountain Gods" by David Williams, Sept. 21, 1980.   Glued to dust cover:  "Dance of the Mountain Gods,"  This dance is a ceremonial dance being performed by the San Carlos Apache in Arizona.  The dancers are to frighten away evil spirits during the young girl's puberty rites.  While the girls are being attended to by their medicine man in a 4 - day ceremony, the "fire dancers" dance all night long around a large fire.  Their appearance and vocal sounds made have a fearful affect on the spectators.  Sept. 21, 1980.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Comanche Shield Dancer
creator: Watchetaker, George "Woogie"
subject: Comanche
description: A painting of three Indian dancers (facing the viewer's left and dancing single file) painted on orange mat board.  Each dancer is distinctly different but all three are wearing body paint, lower back feather bustles, breechclouts, "jingle" bell bands on their calves, and dance moccasins.  They each hold a feather decorated spear in their right hands and decorated shields in their left hands.  The dancer on the viewer's far left is wearing a "war" bonnet and the next two dancers are wearing different versions of roach headdresses.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow from the Oklahoma Indian Art Gallery, Oklahoma City, Oklahoma, January 1981.  On sticker on dust cover:  Shield Dance by George "Woogie" Watchetaker; tribe Comanche; 20" X 24" 1980 Tempera.

title: untitled - Apache Gahn dancer
creator: Palmer, Woodrow Wilson
subject: Miami; Peoria
description: A painting of an apache Gahn dancer facing the viewer's right.  He wears a sack like black mask with an elaborate headpiece attached.  The mask is fastened at the neck with a red scarf.  The dancer's upper body is painted black with a white saw tooth design diagonally across his chest and zigzag lines down his arms.  He wears a yellow-fringed buckskin kilt with metal tinklers attached.  A concha belt holds up the kilt. He also wears hard-soled Apache boots.  Red streamers are attached to his upper arms.  He holds yellow knife like objects in his hands.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow from The Art Market, Tulsa Oklahoma, January 2, 1994. This is one of a set of two paintings done by this artist of apache dancers whose major difference is in the direction that the dancers face. (see JMZ.298) .
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: untitled - Apache Gahn dancer
creator: Palmer, Woodrow Wilson
subject: Miami; Peoria
description: A painting of an apache Gahn dancer who is facing slightly to the viewer's left.  He wears a sack like black mask with an elaborate headpiece attached.  The mask is fastened at the neck with a red scarf.  The dancers upper body and arms are painted black with a white saw-tooth design painted diagonally across his chest and white zigzag designs down his arms.  He wears a yellow-fringed buckskin kilt with metal cones (tinklers) attached.  A concha belt holds up the kilt and he wears hard-soled Apache boots.  Red streamers are attached to his upper arms.  The dancer holds two yellow knife shaped objects in his hands.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow from The Art Market, Tulsa, Oklahoma, January 2, 1994.  This is one of two paintings that the Zarrows purchased that were done by this artist.  Both are of Apache Gahn dancers and their main difference is in the direction the dancer is facing.  (see JMZ.297). APPRAISAL:  $500.00 re. insurance list, 1998.

title: untitled - dancer
creator: Tsatoke, Monroe
subject: Kiowa
description: A print of an Indian dancer facing the viewer with his head turned to the viewer's left.  He is wearing white face and body paint, a yellow and black roach headdress, a beaded choker, beaded bands across his chest, a wide beaded belt, beaded wrist guards, a black breechclout, and beaded moccasins.  He holds a shield head high in his right hand.
provenance: Purchased by Maxine Zarrow at a bank at 71st and Lewis, Tulsa, OK.  The bank was closing and selling its art collection. This is one of the silkscreen prints from the portfolio titled "Kiowa Indian Art" produced in France through the efforts of Dr. O.B. Jocobson of the University of Oklahoma art department in 1929. Taped to dust cover (removed to artist's file):  We believe this is from the Monroe Tsoke (Kiowa) portfolio.  It is a collectors item and (printed) ? to look painted.  There were approximately 300 to 350 of these prints produced in France.  Also on note:  Printed to look painted; Monroe Tsoke Portfolio Kiowa; Art printed in France; 300 - 325 printed.

creator: Vigil, Paul
subject: Tesuque

title: Creek Warrior
creator: Williams, David
subject: Kiowa; Tonkawa; Apache
description: A pencil portrait of a man wearing a turban with ostrich feathers.  He faces slightly to the viewer's left.  There are palm trees and tropical vegetation sketched in the background.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow from David Williams at an art show at the Five Civilized Tribes Museum, Muskogee, Oklahoma.  Mr. Williams had some art to sell in his truck in the parking lot. title: Zuni Warrior
creator: Dishta, Duane
subject: Zuni
description: A painting of a masked dancer facing the viewer's right.  He is wearing a mask that has a thick collar of brown feathers and a long tubular "nose".  He is also wearing a hand-woven embroidered kilt and hard soled buckskin boots that have a band of Spruce branches around the ankle.  There is a bracelet of Spruce branches around his right wrist.  He holds bundles of yucca leaves in his hands.  A cloud formation is outlined behind him.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow through correspondence with Gallery 10, Inc., Scottsdale, Arizona, January 1991.  This painting was one of eleven purchased at this time from Gallery 10.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Pueblo Dancer
creator: Martinez, Julian
subject: San Ildefonso
description: A painting of a Pueblo dancer with long black hair who is facing the viewer's left.  His face is painted black and he is wearing a green shirt, a buckskin kilt, leggings (the right one appears to be beaded) and dance moccasins.  There is a band across his chest from, which hangs what appears to be a tanned animal (deer?) hide.  He holds a bow in his left hand and a spruce branch in his right hand.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow through correspondence with Gallery 10, Inc., Scottsdale, Arizona, December 1, 1990.  This was one of eleven paintings purchased at this time from Gallery 10.   (gallery # A444). Data from Gallery 10:  EX. Jerrold Collins collection, Sedona, AZ.  Acquired by Mr. Collins from Dr. Robert Nelson, Scottsdale, AZ, who owned the paintings approximately 20 years.

title: Hummingbird Kachina
creator: Bahnimptewa, Cliff
subject: Hopi
description: A painting of a dancing masked Kachina who faces the viewer.  His mask has a long black pointed beak, a green face, red "ears" and feathers on top.  In addition it has a ruff or collar of spruce branches.  The dancer has numerous green, yellow, and red circles painted on his body.  He is wearing straps crisp-crossing his chest, a breechclout held up with a red, green, and black hand-woven belt, "jingle" bells around his calves, and hard soled dance boots.  His head is cocked slightly toward his left and his left arm is raised shoulder high.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. jack Zarrow through correspondence with Gallery 10, Inc., Scottsdale, Arizona, December 1, 1990.  This painting was one of eleven paintings purchased at this time from Gallery 10. Data from Gallery 10:  EX. Jerrold Collings collection, Sedona, AZ.  Acquired by Mr. Collings from Dr. Robert Nelson, Scottsdale, AZ, who owned the paintings for approximately 20 years.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Night Dance
creator: David, Neil
subject: Hopi; Tewa
description: A painting on a black background of eight Kachinas and two men at the entrance to a Kiva.  There are two Mana Kachinas (female) and six Longhair Kachinas, all are wearing the traditional masks.  One of the Longhair Kachinas is descending the Kiva ladder and another is preparing to follow him.  An elder wrapped in a blanket is standing to the viewer's right of the Kiva, another man stands beside him holding a kerosene lantern.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow at The Art Market's "Sale of Important Art", Tulsa, Oklahoma, April 14, 1991. Sticker on dust cover:  Property of Carolyn Heath loaned to Pueblo Petroleum Co.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Cloud Dancers
creator: Pena, Jose Encarnacion/So Kwa A Weh
subject: San Ildefonso
description: A painting of six identical Pueblo dancers in a line facing the viewer.  They are wearing a headpiece (tablita like), a Spruce bough collar, white hand-woven embroidered kilts, and hard-soled dance boots.  They each hold a rattle in their right hands and a Spruce branch in their left hands.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow, when, where, how, and price unavailable.

provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow from Robert F. Nichols, Santa Fe, New Mexico, February 1, 1994.  (gallery #93.21).

title: Straight dancer
creator: Blackowl, Archie
description: A painting of a pow-wow straight dancer.  He faces the viewer's left with his back slightly to the viewer.  He is wearing a roach headdress, a gold shirt, a long trailer with silver conchas hanging down his back, a red breechclout, blue trousers with a strip of beading down the sides, a double row of "jingle" bells around each upper calf, and beaded moccasins.  He holds a feather fan in his left hand.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow at the Cherokee National Museum's "Trail of Tears Show", June 19, 1981.  Previous framer:  Sissor-tail Frame Shop, Oklahoma City, OK.

title: Prime rider
creator: Abeyta, Narcisco
subject: Navajo
description: A non-realistic painting of a woman in a full gathered blue and green skirt riding (astride, without a saddle) a paint horse.  The woman and horse face the viewer's left.  The horse appears to be rearing as the woman strikes him with a quirt that she holds above her head in her right hand and her left hand holds the single rein.  On the horse's left flank there appears to be a brand - NA.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow at the Oklahoma Indian Art Gallery, Oklahoma City, Oklahoma, Jul6 30, 1992. On back of painting: (HA-SO-DE) Narcisco P. Abeyta; Tribe - Navajo; Prime Rider and (Winner).

title: Green Corn Ceremonial
creator: White Deer, Gary
subject: Choctaw
description: A painting of thirteen figures, dancing around a campfire in dance grounds.  These figures are seen to the viewer's right.  To the viewer's left and partially superimposed over the dance scene is an ear of multi-colored Indian corn and the heads of a man and a woman.  The man wears a red turban and the woman's head is silhouetted against a moon.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarow at the Five Civilized Tribes Museum's Annual Art Show, Muskogee, Oklahoma, October 14, 1979. Label glued to dust cover:  #80 "Green Corn Ceremonial" by Gary White Deer (Choctaw) casein.  (in ink) "2nd Prize - Choctaw and Indian Heritage; Awards.  '79 5 Civilized Tribes Muskogee.

title: Stickers
creator: Stroud, Virginia Alice
subject: Cherokee; Creek
description: A painting of four young women, a little girl and a young man.  The young man is sitting down taking stickers out of his foot.  The little girl (viewer's left of painting) is crying and reaching to be picked up and one of the young women is reaching for her.  Another two of the young women (viewer's right hand side) are hanging onto a third as they remove stickers from their feet.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow at the Indian Paintbrush Gallery in Siloam Springs, AR on August 30, 1991.

title: Southern Plains Fancy Dancer
creator: Geionety, Ron W.
subject: Kiowa
description: A drawing of a fancy war dancer done predominately in red.  The dancer faces the viewer and looks to the viewer's right.  He wears a feather headdress, upper and lower back feather bustles, a beaded and fringed shoulder wide cape, hare bone pipe breast plate, a decorated blue breechclout, "jingle" bell bands just below his knees, beaded bow guards on his wrists, and beaded moccasins.  His right hand holds a spear over his head and his left hand holds a feather fan at his left side.  His left leg is bent and raised hip high as he dances.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow from Ron Geionety at the Tallasi Winter Festival, Tulsa, Oklahoma, December 3, 1993. Written on backing (cardboard):  Southern Plains Fancy Dancer; Ron W. Geionety (signature) 12/3/93. Glued to backing:  a brief biographical sketch (see artist file for copy).

title: Homeward
creator: Hood, Rance
subject: Comanche
description: A painting of an Indian man wrapped in a buffalo robe riding a brown and white paint horse in a snowstorm.  They ride toward the viewer's left.  The man's face is painted, as is the horse.  The man holds a spear in his right hand and a shield (decorated with an eagle) in his left hand.  The man's legs are wrapped in fur and he uses another hide as a saddle.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow at The Art Market's "Sale of Important Art", April 12, 1991.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Comanche Scout
creator: Hood, Rance
subject: Comanche
description: A painting of an Indian man riding a brown and white paint horse toward the viewer.  The horse looks toward the viewer's left and the man looks toward the viewer's right.  The man is using a buffalo hide as a saddle and holds a bow in his left hand as he guides the horse (using a rein) with his right hand.  The horse's hooves are all off the ground as he runs.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow from the Indian Paintbrush Gallery, Siloam Springs, Arkansas, October 27, 1980.

title: Leaving for the Spring Buffalo Hunt
creator: Echohawk, Brummett
subject: Pawnee
description: Painting of an Indian hunting party (eight men on horses) as they leave camp and cross a stream.  They are smiling as they move toward the viewer and slightly toward the left.  In the background there are three teepees and people waving.  The light indicates it is early in the morning.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow from Brummett Echohawk, Tulsa, Oklahoma, July 8, 1980. On card glued to dust cover:  "Leaving for the Spring Buffalo Hunt"  1976 . Data from Artist:  "Morning Hunt or river Crossing (Leaving for the Spring Buffalo Hunt); Tempera; Art size: 8" x 14"; date painted:  1976; This depicts the spirit of an early spring hunt.  Both men and horses are glad to get out of camp.  Anticipating a good hunt, the men laugh and talk.   Children follow the hunters out of the village.  Fed by melting snow, the stream ripples with new life.  A Killdeer in the foreground is looking for a nesting spot as daylight breaks in the east.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Flute Song
creator: Pahsetopah, Loren
subject: Osage; Cherokee
description: A painting of a Plains Indian man silhouetted against the moon as he plays a flute for a young woman seated at his feet.  The scene is painted against a black background.  The man, who is standing and facing the viewer's left, is wearing a "war" bonnet, a hare bone choker, a red breechclout, and fringed and beaded buckskin leggings.  The woman, who is seated on a buffalo hide spread on a rack, is wearing a fringed and beaded buckskin dress, a hare bone choker and breastplate, and fully beaded boots.  She holds a beaded feather fan in her hands that rest in her lap.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow at Ruth's Turquoise, Tulsa, OK, November 1, ca. 1989.

title: Eagle Dancers
creator: Secatero, John
subject: Navajo
description: A painting of two Pueblo eagle dancers.  They face each other and the center of the painting.  They are wearing eagle masks, arm ornaments made with feathers to look like wings, hand-woven embroidered kilts, and hand-woven belts.  Behind the dancers is a wood ladder that is leaning up against a Pueblo wall.  The dance appears to be taking place in the Pueblo�s plaza area.

title: When the Underwater People Talked
creator: Wall, Ralph
description: A painting of two Plains Indians beside a body of water.  One of the men (furthest to viewer's left) is on his hands and knees looking at a disturbance in the water.  The second man who is wearing a horned headdress, stands in a slightly crouched position at the first man's left shoulder.  The second man holds a peace pipe in his left hand while he covers his mouth with his right hand.  His shoulders are painted green and he has a bow and arrow quiver across his back.  In the background are three Indian men on horseback and two riderless horses.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow from Ralph Wall, New Braunfels, Texas by special order, May 8, 1980. Brass plaque:  "When the Underwater People Talked"; Ralph Wall. On back of painting:  "When the Underwater People Talked"' 1979, Ralph Wall (signature).

title: Oil and the Osage
creator: Echohawk, Brummett
subject: Pawnee
description: A painting of an oil well "blowing out" (viewer's right - background) and scaring two horses that were pulling a wagon with a man, woman, and child in it.  The horses are bolting toward the viewer's left, the man is trying to control them and the woman and child are hanging on for dear life.  A small dog is running in the foreground.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow by special order from Brummett Echohawk, Tulsa, Oklahoma, July 8, 1980. Data from artist: Tempera; Art size:  7" X 12"; Date painted:  1979; This depicts an Osage family in their wagon, going to town, just as a well comes in, frightening the horses. subject: Pawnee

title: Red Shirt, Sioux
creator: Echohawk, Brummett
subject: Pawnee
description: A head and shoulder portrait of a man facing the viewer's left.  At the back of his head is a long narrow braid that hangs down over his left shoulder. title: Noon Chuck Wagon or The Smell of Beef and Beans
creator: Echohawk, Brummett
subject: Pawnee
description: A painting of a chuck wagon under a tarp shelter with six men sitting or standing while they eat (viewer's left) while two cowboys on horses ride toward the viewer on the viewer's right.  In the distant background is a herd of cattle.  To the left of the riders is a corral and behind the riders some saddled horses (the remuda).
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow from Brummett Echohawk, Tulsa, Oklahoma, July 24, 1991. On brass plaque:  "The Smell of Beef and Beans" by Brummett Echohawk.  Glued to dust cover (from original framing): "Noon Chuck Wagon" or "The Smell of Beef and Beans"; Echohawk w/outline of hawk; 1983, Tempera painting; To Jack and Maxine Brummett Echohawk (signature)  24 July, 1991.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

subject: Cherokee

provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow from George Cochran at his home in Tahlequah, Oklahoma, ca. 1980. On stretcher:  "Wolf Collar", 1975; Medicine Man, Blackfoot, Montana or E. Oregon, Bitterroots Mountains; by George Cochran.

title: Kiowa-Apache Manatidie Dancer
creator: Wall, Ralph
description: A waist up portrait of an Indian dancer facing the viewer's left.  He is wearing a roach headdress, eyeglasses, beaded bands around his braids, a blue neck scarf, and a pink shirt.  In his right hand he holds a fur wrapped lance and in his left hand a feathered fan.  He appears to be singing.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow from Ralph Wall, New Braunfels, Texas, through correspondence, May 18, 1980. For explanation of painting see artist's file. On back of painting:  "Manatidie Dancer" 1979, Ralph Wall.

subject: Cherokee

provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow from George Cochran at his home in Tahlequah, Oklahoma, ca. 1980.

title: Indian Smoking Pipe
creator: Tartsah, Jim
subject: Kiowa
description: A painting of a Plains Indian man sitting cross legged on a hill while he smokes a peace pipe.  He faces the viewer's left.  He is wearing a "war" bonnet and a red and black breechclout.  He has red paint on his cheek and around his eye.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow but data not available.

title: Two step
creator: Blackowl, Archie
subject: Cheyenne
description: A painting of an Indian man and woman dressed in pow-wow finery dancing side by side while holding hands.  They face the viewer.  He is dressed in a roach headdress, beaded shoulder cape, upper and lower back feathered bustles, a red breechclout with a beaded belt, beaded armbands and wrist bow guards, "jingle" bell calf bands, and beaded moccasins.  The woman is wearing a beaded white buckskin dress, a long hare bone pipe breastplate, and beaded dance boots.  She has a drawstring bag hanging on her left forearm.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow at the Indian Paintbrush gallery, Siloam Springs, Arkansas, August 30, 1991.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Southern Plains Fancy Dancer
creator: Geionety, Ron W.
subject: Kiowa
description: a painting of a pow-wow fancy war dancer done predominantly in yellow.  He faces the viewer with his head turned to his right and looking toward the ground.  He wears the traditional upper and lower back feather bustles, roach headdress, and breechclout.  He holds beaded and feathered fans in both hands.  His left hand is raised over his head and his right is lowered close to his right knee.  His left knee is at waist height with the foot crossed over his right knee.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow from Ron Geionety at the Tallasi Winter Festival, Tulsa, Oklahoma, December 3, 1993. On cardboard backing:  Southern Plains Fancy Dancer; 12-3-93 Ron W. Geionety (signature) 125.

title: Vision Seeker
creator: Montgomery, Gary
subject: Seminole
description: A painting of a young man who is seated cross-legged on the ground with a blanket draped around his hips.  He faces slightly to the left and his hands are raised toward the sky as he looks up.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow from Henry Belink of Santa Fe, New Mexico at their home in Tulsa, OK, June 6, 1981.  Mr. Belink brought the artwork to Tulsa to sell.  The Zarrows purchased five paintings at this time. Previous framer:  Pirates Alley, Oklahoma City, OK.

title: Making of a Bow
creator: Underwood, Ted
subject: Chicksaw
description: A painting of a man sitting cross-legged on the ground facing the viewer.  He holds a long stick in his left hand as he uses a knife to shape it.  He sits on a raised area with a sun over his head.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow at the Five civilized Tribes Museum Artists Exhibition, Muskogee, Oklahoma, October 14, 1979.  This painting won a 2nd Prize in the Chicksaw division.  It was one of three paintings and two sculptures purchased by the Zarrows at the exhibition. On sticker on back:  Z1 Underwood Indian w/knife.

title: Stirrings of a pot
creator: Cokendolpher, Eunice Loraine Mund
description: A painting of four ceramic pots in various stages of decoration.  On the viewer's left (almost out of the painting) is an unpainted ceramic pot while on the viewer's far right is a fully painted pot.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Zarrow from the artist at Mayfest, Tulsa, OK, May 1979. The following information was tapped to the dust cover:  "Best of Show Walters, OK; May 1979; "Gallery on the Green"; Citation award at Graham, TX art show   May 1979.  Judge stated this would have been second but I had already received 1st on another painting and only one cash award could be awarded per person. "Stirrings of a Pot"; Thank You; Eunice Cokendolpher; I feel you got a bargain!!
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Tail dancer
creator: Crumbo, Woodrow Wilson
subject: Potawatomi
description: A silkscreen of a war dancer as he performs a portion of the dance called The Tail Dance.  He appears to move toward the viewer�s left (feet and knees) with his upper torso facing the viewer, and his head turned to the viewer�s right.  As he moves both knees are bent, his left knee is raised waist high, and his right foot is on the ground.  His body (except for portions of his face and hands) is painted black with red, yellow, and gray designs on his body and red and white on his face.  He wears a roach headdress, feathered rosettes on his upper arms, a lower back feather bustle, a red breechclout, ankle bells, and beaded moccasins.  A scalp hangs from his belt.  In his right hand he holds a feather and in his left a feather fan.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow at a store in Springdale, Arkansas. See artist's file for description of "Tail Dance".
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Last sunset
creator: Crumbo, Woodrow Wilson
subject: Potawatomi
description: A print of a gray haired Indian man sitting on a rock looking at a broken bow that he holds in his right hand.  He faces the viewer's left and has a buffalo robe wrapped around his hips.  His old horse stands behind him, head hanging.  There is an Indian saddle on the horse that has a decorated shield hanging from it.  Two vultures are just beyond the horse.  The sun is setting in the distance.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow at the Gilcrease Museum Gift Shop, Tulsa, Oklahoma, November 11, 1991. On dust cover:  #1116 and "About the artist ... (see artist's file - biographical data).

title: Feather dance
creator: Crumbo, Woodrow Wilson
subject: Potawatomi
description: A print of a Plains Indian dancer in an elaborate costume.  His head is turned to the viewer's right and his legs are turned toward the viewer's left.  He wears a roach headdress, feathered rosettes on his upper arms and lower legs, a feathered tail bustle, and a red breechclout with a beaded belt.  His body is painted blue with cream, gray, and red designs.  He holds a fan in his right hand and a flute in his left hand.  In addition he wears numerous other beaded ornaments.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow at a store in Springdale, Arkansas. See artist's file for description of "Tail Dance". See artist's file for description of the "Feather Dance".

title: untitled - young boy eating
creator: Tiger, Jerome
subject: Creek; Seminole
description: A drawing of a young boy sitting on the floor (facing viewer) with a bowl between his legs as he licks a spoon and looks up at someone above him. title: untitled - eagle dancer
creator: Tsatoke, Monroe
subject: Kiowa
description: A painting of a man wearing an eagle costume as he dances.  He faces slightly to the viewer's right.  He wears an eagle headdress, feathered arm decorations, a feathered tail bustle, a yellow kilt with a red zigzag design near the hem, "jingle" bell calf bands, goat hair ankle bands, and beaded moccasins. title: War Dancer
creator: Mopope, Stephen/Qued-koi
subject: Kiowa
description: A painting of an Indian man dancing a fancy war dance.  He faces the viewer with his head turned slightly to the viewer's right.  He wears a roach headdress, feathered arm rosettes, a tail bustle, blue breechclout with a beaded belt, a vest like garment with beaded medallions, "jingle" bell calf bands, goat hair ankle bands, and beaded moccasins.  His left leg is bent at the knee and raised toward the back and his arms swing as he dances.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow from Henry B. Belink of Santa Fe, New Mexico in their home in Tulsa, Oklahoma, June 22, 1981. Data from Mr. Belink:  "Dancer" by Stephen Mopope. title: Wedding ceremony
creator: Blue Eagle, Acee
subject: Creek; Pawnee
description: A painting of an Indian man and woman standing in front of a tree.  They face the viewer and the woman is to the viewer's left and slightly in front of the man.  The woman is dressed in a yellow fringed and beaded buckskin dress and fully beaded boots.  She holds a beaded feather fan in her left hand.  The man wears a three-feather headdress, a blue bead choker, a band across his chest that holds a bow and arrow quiver, a blue breechclout, bead decorated buckskin leggings, and beaded moccasins.  His face and arms are decorated with paint designs.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow from The Mobile Art Gallery, D. F. Henry Company, Tulsa, Oklahoma, December 15, 1980.

title: Ready to dance
creator: Atencio, Gilbert Benjamin
subject: San Ildefonso
description: A painting of a man dressed as a Koshare (clown) Kachina as he prepares to take part in a ceremony.  His body is decorated with the traditional black and white stripes and face paint.  His hair is tied in two "pony tails" (one on each side of his head) and he wears a hand-woven breechclout.  He holds some Spruce boughs in his right hand.  He is slightly crouched and his hands are in front of him as he starts to dance.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow through correspondence with Gallery 10, Inc., Scottsdale, Arizona, December 1, 1990. Data from Gallery 10:  EX. Jerrold Collings collection, Sedona, AZ, acquired by Mr. Collings from Dr. Robert Nelson, Scottsdale, AZ, who owned the painting for approximately 20 years.  Early painting.

title: The First Rain Call By A Young Rain Priest of Zuni
creator: Sandy, Percy  KaiSa
subject: Zuni
description: A painting of two ceremonial figures.  The first figure (on the viewer's left) is dancing and holding out two feathers toward stylized clouds.  He is facing the viewer's right and wearing a hand-woven embroidered sash and kilt.  The second figure (on the viewer's right) is facing the viewer's left.  He is blowing on a long flute or pipe that is pointed toward what appears to be a spring.  He is wrapped in an embroidered blanket and is wearing leather leggings.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow at the Hansen Gallery, Santa Fe, NM, February 25, 1991. The painting was from the estate of Ernest Blumenshein (1874 1960).  At his death his daughter Helen Blumenshein (1909 1989) inherited it.  At her death it went to a cousin who lived in Santa Fe and was then purchased from her by the Hansen Gallery in 1990.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: The Golden Years
creator: Love, Ralph
description: A painting of a desert canyon as seen from the floor of the canyon.  The sun shines down on some trees (smoke trees) turning them to orange and gold against the shadowed rock face of the canyon wall.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow from Ralph Love, Temecula, California, April, 1980.  The Zarrows had seen other "Smoke Trees" by Mr. Love and requested he let them know when one was available. On dust cover:  "The Golden Years" painted in "Painted Canyon" near Palm Springs, CA; by Ralph Love; Smoke Tree; 36 X 30 oil.

title: untitled - man in wheelchair
creator: Rockwell, Norman
description: A reproduction of a painting depicting a very proud looking man wearing bib-overalls rolling his wheel chair toward the viewer's right.  The man holds a yellow lunch box on his lap and a check from Goodwill Industries in his left hand as he speeds his wheelchair along with his right hand.
provenance: Given to Jack Zarrow in appreciation of his efforts on behalf of the Capitol Fund Drive for Goodwill Industries, Tulsa, Oklahoma, May 19, 1994.  Peggy Helmerich also received the same print for her efforts as Co-Chairman. Below Print:  This print is from the original Norman Rockwell painting presented to the Pittsfield, Massachusetts Goodwill in 1958 which now hangs in the Goodwill Industries International Offices in Bethesda, Maryland.  It expresses the jubilation felt by people with disabilities when they earn a wage in the workforce and has become a symbol of Goodwill Accomplishments.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Independence Day in Ghana
creator: Bartimeus, Albert Osabu
description: An impressionistic painting of a closely grouped crowd of people.  The man on the viewer's left is carrying a green flag.  To his left is a man shooting a gun in the air and to his left (viewer's right) is a man playing a flute like musical instrument.  The people behind them are in distinct - only suggested.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow in Accra, Ghana, Africa, January 2, 1978.  Mr. Zarrow wanted some paintings of the Ghanaian culture and his friend, Bill St. Johns acquired four paintings by A. O. Bartimeus for him.

title: Mourning party
creator: Bartimeus, Albert Osabu
description: An impressionistic painting of a group of women under a tent like structure in the middle of some buildings (city street?).  There are 10 figures.  Slightly to the viewer's right of center, is a woman dressed in blue being supported by two other women.  To their left are three seated women, one (in blue) with her head bowed.

title: untitled - three men and a ball
creator: unknown (A. O. Bartimeus ?) (Albert Osabu)
description: A somewhat abstract painting of three men, one in front of the others.  They are dressed in blue and wear pillbox shaped hats.  The man in front is singing and holding a large ball in his hands.  The man to his right (over his right shoulder) is playing a flute and the man behind him, to his left, is singing.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow in Accra, Ghana, Africa, ca. 1978.  At Mr. Zarrow's request, Bill St. Johns, a friend of his, acquired four paintings by this artist for him.  Mr. Zarrow later learned that A. O. Bartimeus was one of the leading artists in Ghana.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Avenue of trees (Bourre Gardens)
creator: Bartimeus, Albert Osabu
description: An impressionistic painting of a road or path with a row of trees on both sides - their branches meet overhead.  In the viewer's upper right a city can be seen.  Two people (backs to viewer) are walking down the road.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow in Kumassi, Ghana, Africa, January 2, 1978.  It is a painting of an area of the Bourre Gardens. title: Ball of wisdom
creator: Bartimeus, Albert Osabu
description: An impressionistic painting of a gathering of people (+ or - 15).  In the foreground (to viewer's left) is a man holding a large round ceramic vessel with a red rope around it.  In front of him (center of painting) is a man wearing green pants with his back to the viewer.  To the viewer's right is a man with a drum hanging from his shoulder by a red strap.  Everyone is bare foot.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow in Accra, Ghana, Africa, January 2, 1978.  Mr. Zarrow wanted some paintings of the Ghanan culture and his friend, Bill St. Johns acquired four paintings by A. O. Bartimeus for him.  Mr. Zarrow later learned that A. O. Bartimeus was one of the most prominent artists in Ghana.

title: Bronco rider
creator: Cochran, George M.
subject: Cherokee
description: A painting of a cowboy riding a bucking horse.  He is holding on to the bronc saddle with his left hand and his right hand is in the air over his head.  His legs are bent and in the air as he prepares to spur the horse's shoulders.  He looks determined and seems to be enjoying the ride.  Painted on blue mat board.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow from George Cochran at his his home in Tahlequah, Oklahoma, ca. 1980. APPRAISAL:  $100.00 re. insurance list, 1998.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Bull rider
creator: Cochran, George M.
subject: Cherokee
description: A painting of a man in a cowboy hat, chaps and cowboy boots riding a bucking bull.  His right hand holds on to the bull rope while his left arm swings free and his chaps fly in the air.  The bull and rider face the viewer.  The painting was painted on yellow mat board.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow from George Cochran at his home in Tahlequah, Oklahoma, ca. 1980. On back of frame:  "Bull Rider" 1980.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Lung Shot #3
creator: Echohawk, Brummett
subject: Pawnee
description: A drawing of an Indian man riding a brown and white paint horse at a full run as he shoots an arrow into the right side of a running buffalo bull.  The rider and the bull run toward the viewer's right.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow at the Gilcrease Museum's 1st (unofficial) Rendezvous, June 14, 1979.  Brummett Echohawk who was one of two �Quick draw� artists to give an exhibition of their art did this drawing.  The drawing as then auctioned and Mr. Zarrow was the successful bidder. On dust cover:  1st Gilcrease Rendezvous, June 14, 1975; Quick Draw. Taped to dust cover (removed to artist's file):  6/14/79 Pawnee Indian Rider; Pawnee Buffalo hunter "Lung Shot 3".
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: As One
creator: Roye, Burgess
subject: Ponca
description: A painting of two faces (man and woman) facing the viewers left.  A woman's face overlaps the back of a man's face (he has two feathers in his hair).  These heads seem to float in space over a Plains Indian teepee.  Their long hair flows downward and connects with the teepee.  This painting was done on an orange mat board.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow from the Gentry Gallery, Tulsa, Oklahoma, October 31, 1980.  The Gentry Gallery and the McDonnell-Douglas - Tulsa Management Club held this exhibition as a fundraiser for the Oklahoma Indian Art Program's Scholarship Fund. Taped to dust cover (removed to artist's file): as one; in the image of oneness we have become; in thought of our dream as together we are to become it's truth...as the rain joins the dried earth and brings it coolness; as the wind brings forth a seed to become as a witness to our lifes' greatest journey through lovingness that we might grow with all our truths as one.  burgess roye
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: untitled - fall landscape
creator: D'Mude
description: A painting of a fall landscape.  A path goes from the viewer's lower left to the viewer's right and into the middle ground where there is a figure walking through some trees.  At the viewer's lower left at the side of the path are what appear to be four Birch trees that have lost their leaves.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow on a trip to Europe, possibly Italy.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: James Bigheart
creator: Echohawk, Brummett
subject: Pawnee
description: A head and shoulders portrait of a man with his black hair worn medium long and cut off straight across in line with his jaw.  He wears a black suit coat, a blue and white bow tie, and a vest.  The vest has a design of yellow medallions edged with red and blue against a black background.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow from Brummett Echohawk, Tulsa, OK, July 8, 1980. On stretcher:  James Bigheart 1838 - 1908; Full blood Osage; Born in St Paul, Kansas then an Osage village.  Buried near now Barnsdall, Okla. (previously Bigheart, Oklal.) Chief James Bigheart - led in organizing the Osage Nation under a written constitution.  Pun-Kah-!i-Tah-An-Kah Known as "Big Jim" called "Moses of the Osages" for his role in preserving the mineral rights in common for the 2229 tribal members. First elected principal Chief in 1882 - Osage nation comprises 1,476,539 acres.  Served his people as their leader or Chief from 1875 - 1900.  Negotiated and signed the first blanket oil and gas sale in 1896 - Fathered the "headright" system. 14
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Trader on Rock
creator: Fife, Jimmie Carole
subject: Creek
description: A painting of a man wearing a gray turban standing with his left foot on a rock.  He faces the viewer with his hands spread as though explaining something.  He wears pantaloons with green printed garters and along tan shirt with pink ruffles at the hem, cuffs, and shoulder seams.  The strap of a beaded blue bandoleer bag hangs across his chest and the bag rests on his right hip.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow at the Gentry Gallery, Tulsa, Oklahoma, October 31, 1980.  The gallery and the McDonnell-Douglas - Tulsa Management Club held this exhibition as a fundraiser for the Oklahoma Indian Art Program's Scholarship fund. Sticker on dust cover:  Z-6; fife; trader on Rock. On dust cover:  Z-6; Fife; Trader on Rock, Z-7.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

creator: unknown
description: A collage of flowers constructed of multi-colored cut out children's handprints.  There is one large many petaled flower in the center and two single hand print flowers - one on each side of the large one.
provenance: A gift to Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow from Family and Children's Service in appreciation of their support, 1979.

title: Buffalo and Deer Dance
creator: Popovi Da (Red Fox)/Martinez, Antonio Jose
subject: San Ildefonso
description: A painting of 12 dancing figures  4 deer dancers, 2 antelope dancers, 3 mountain sheep dancers, 2 buffalo dancers and 1 female dancer dressed in the female Buffalo Dance conventional ceremonial dress (handwoven, one shoulder dress with an embroidered hem which is tied with a multicolored handwoven sash).
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow from Howard Huston of Hurst, Texas in June of 1996. Written on the back of the painting:  Tony Martinez (Popovi Da); San Ildefonso Pueblo; Buffalo and Deer Dance; 1937. Stamped on the back: "The Studio, U.S. Indian School, Santa Fe, New Mexico." Sticker on the back of the painting )viewer's lower left corner) "Collection of Dorothy Dunn, 4175 Page Mill Rd., Palo Alto, Calf, U.S.A."

title: Mow-Way 1871 Comanche
creator: Watkins, James
description: A head and shoulder portrait of an Indian man.  He faces the viewer with his head turned slightly to his right.  He wears what looks like a bear's claw in his hair on the left side.  A small braid hangs down from where the claw is attached.  His clothing is a brown vest over a gray shirt.  At his throat is a large disk (shell?) on a leather thong.  The drawing is done on aqua mat board.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow at The Art Market, Tulsa, Oklahoma, October 10, 1979.  This was one of two drawings by Mr. Watkins that they purchased at this time.  The other one was "Iron Sack, Chief of Kiowa-Apache". Card taped to dust cover:  Mow-Way 1871 Comanche (on reverse - The Art Market, Tulsa, OK).
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Iron Sack Chief of Kiowa-Apache
creator: Watkins, James
description: A head and shoulder portrait of an Indian man.  He faces slightly to the viewer's left.  He wears a bird headpiece and a fur wrapped braid hangs down over his left shoulder.  Long hare bone pipe pendent earrings hang down from his ear lobes. He is drawn in brown with a yellow background.  The drawing was done on aqua mat board.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow at The Art Market, Tulsa, Oklahoma, October 8, 1979.  One of two drawings by James Watkins that the Zarrows purchased at this time.  The other one was "Mow-Way Comanche".

title: Gypsy at Tonkawa
creator: Reynolds, H. Bishop
description: A painting of an oil field.  In the foreground are: a pipe rack, a doghouse, a storage building and various equipment.  To the viewer's right is a early vintage automobile.  In the center of the painting is a wood derrick with a walking beam at its base.  In the background are six additional wood derricks.  The sign on the doghouse or office says "Gypsy Oil Co.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow, December 14, 1974. On dust cover:  "Gypsy at Tonkawa"; 12-14-74. Taped to dust cover (removed to artist's file): "Gypsy at Tonkawa"; $150.00; (written in different ink - 12-14-1974 $100.00).

title: Landmark tree
creator: Calle, Paul
description: A reproduction of a drawing of a very large old tree with a Trapper (left side of tree) leading a horse with a woman on it.  The horse is also pulling a fur pelt loaded travois.  The lead rope of a loaded pack mule is attached to the travois.  Behind this are another man and two more pack mules.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow at the Reading and Bates Art Sale to benefit the Thomas Gilcrease Museum Association, Tulsa, Oklahoma, May 14,1898. title: Leaving for the trading post
creator: Beaver, Fred
subject: Creek
description: A reproduction of a painting of a man, woman and child (facing the viewer's left) as they are about to get in a canoe type boat in a bayou.  They are dressed in the traditional appliqued Seminole clothing and the man has a sack of belongings over his right shoulder.  His left hand rests on a walking stick.  The man is in front with the child between him and the woman.  The woman's hands rest on the child�s shoulders.  A large orange setting sun is behind them.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow but the details of the purchase are not available. Printed signature:  Fred Beaver . 77. Glued to dust cover:  Fred Beaver; Fred Beaver, Creek, paints to "help bridge the gap". "My paintings show the non-Indians what the original Indians looked like, how they lived and worked, and so there is more knowledge and understanding." Beaver, a noted vocalist, is a self-taught artist who paints while listening to music.  His paintings have won over 200 top awards including the grand prize at Philbrook in Tulsa, in 1958.  He was first winner of the Waite Phillips Indian Artist Award in 1963.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Old Man of the Blackfoot
creator: Terpning, Howard
description: A reproduction of a head and shoulder portrait of a man wearing braids and a yellow hat with a sagging brim, an orange hat band, and feathers on the left side.  He is also wearing a blue shirt and an orange blanket around his shoulders.  He faces the viewer.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow at the Gilcrease Museum's "Rendezvous, 1985", Tulsa, Oklahoma, May 1985.  The original painting is in the Gilcrease Museum's collection. On sticker on dust cover (removed to artist's file):  Z-12; Terpning; Old Man w/hat. On card glued to dust cover:  The oil painting, "Old Man of the Blackfoot" was painted by Howard Terpning, The Gilcrease Rendezvous artist for 1985.  The painting is now in the collection of the Thomas Gilcrease Institute of American History and Art, Tulsa, Oklahoma. This limited edition print of "Old Man of the Blackfoot" was issued May, 1985 by the Thomas Gilcrease Museum Association to commemorate the 1985 Gilcrease Rendezvous exhibition of works by Howard Terpning. This is number 7/300 of the signed limited edition print.

title: Flute Player
creator: Haney, Enoch Kelley
subject: Seminole; Creek
description: A reproduction of a painting of an Indian man (the artist's father, Woodrow Haney) playing a flute.  He faces the viewer.  The man has long gray hair and wears four feathers on the back of his head.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow but the details of its acquisition are not available. Glued to dust cover:  American Indian Arts Collection, Shawnee, OK; Flute Player by Enoch Kelley Haney Guarantee this limited edition print id a mechanically reproduced lithograph signed and numbered by the artist.  Print No. 118 of 750 Enoch Kelley Haney.  This print is made and distributed by AIAC who guarantees the print plates have been destroyed.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Spirit Horse and Warrior

subject: Creek; Seminole

In the viewer's lower right corner is a scaffold burial and cloud like lines go from it to the horse and rider.  In the upper right corner is a red circle with the image of an Indian man wearing a "war" bonnet in it.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow but the details of the acquisition are not available.

title: Zuni Comanche Dancer
creator: Herrera, Joe
subject: Cochiti
description: A painting of a single figure facing the viewer's right.  The figure is wearing braids and a feather decorated headband.  It is wearing a white buckskin shirt that has long wide fringe hanging from it, a fringed kilt with a fox skin hanging down the back, leather leggings, and dance moccasins.  It its left hand it holds a stick to which a drum is attached and in its right hand a drumstick.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow from Howard Huston of Hurst, Texas, June 2, 1995. On Dust Cover:  "Joe Herrera original watercolor, ca. 1950, Zuni Comanche Dancer; purchased from Howard Huston, Hurst TX, June 2, 1995."

title: 200 Years With Old Glory
creator: Juharos, Stephen
description: A reproduction of a painting depicting "the birth and growth of our nation."  An image of George Washington is at the center of this circular painting and around him are scenes from U.S. history - Pilgrims arriving, pioneers, Civil War, WW I and II, men landing on the moon, farmers, and the liberty bell.
provenance: Purchased by Jack Zarrow by special order from Stephen Juharos, Sedona, Arizona, May 18, 1976.  Mr. Zarrow visited the artist's studio and was very impressed with this print.  He asked for print number 1776 but was told it hadn't been printed yet.  The artist said he would send it to him when it was available. Post card taped to dust cover (removed to artist's file):  May 17, 1976  "Dear Sir:  Today the Print #1776 has been sent to your address.  Thank you Prof. Juharos (signature)  Also on Dust cover:  Advertisement for print with information about the artist and the print.  The data is from Commemorative Imports, Bayport, MN.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: �Gaff � Staff�
creator: Petersen, Eric
description: An etching of a female scarecrow with a large sunflower for a face.  She is wearing a blue blouse that has gray sleeves.  Over the blouse she is wearing a multi-patterned sleeveless dress that has the two gingerbread like figures in the middle of the skirt.  She also wears red and black checked stockings.  In her right hand she holds a basket full of eggs and on her right shoulder sits a white bird.  In her left hand she holds a fish and there is a shepherds crook attached to her left arm.  Two corn plants are on each side and slightly back of her.  On the ground to her right are a beehive and a small dog.  On the ground to her left is a cat.  In the distance are two hills with a ram on the one to the viewer�s right and a ewe on the one to the viewer�s left.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow at a NARSAD Artwork Exhibit which was held at The Gilcrease Museum, Tulsa OK, Nov. 17, 1999.  The exhibition was to benefit the Metal Health Association in Tulsa, Inc.  In addition to this painting they purchased two others, one, �Forest Glen�, they donated to the Metal Health Association, and the second, �Face to Face�, by Susan Foldy, they gave as a gift.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: untitled � 7 yeibichai dancers
creator: Tsinajinnie, Andrew Van
subject: Navajo

They are all dressed the same � high top dance boots, gray kilt, silver and turquoise concha belt, silver and turquoise wrist guards and a round topped headdress with a green ruff around the neck.  The four at the back face the viewer�s left and the three in the foreground face the viewer�s right. title: �Up�
creator: Duecker, Otto
description: A painting of the side of a cardboard box with a square opening cut in it, creating two horizontal flaps.  The upper flap is slightly open and the bottom one forms a self.  On this shelf are three strawberries and two drops of water.  To the left of the shelf, on the body of the box is printed the letter U.  On the right side of the shelf is printed an arrow pointing up.  Below the shelf on the right side is a tear in the surface of the box and a water drop.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow at the American Art in Miniature 1999 wall sale, Gilcrease Museum, Tulsa, OK, December 145, 1999. Poulson and a sculpture, �Feeding Frenzy� (JMZ.S72) by Daniel Kronberg.

title: Benton
creator: Cochran, George M.
subject: Cherokee
description: A charcoal portrait of Thomas Hart Benton.  He faces the viewer and has his chin resting on the back of his right hand.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow at an antique store in downtown Tahlequah, OK, ca. 1996.  The woman proprietor believed it to be a self-portrait by Thomas Hart Benton, in part because the drawing came from Kansas City.  The Zarrows did not think it was by Benton and wanted to have it authenticated.  They offered the woman half of what she was asking for the drawing and agreed to pay the balance if it was by Benton.  The staff at The Gilcrease Museum examined it and determined it was a drawing of Benton done by Cherokee Indian artist, George M. Cochran.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: untitled � three blanket wrapped Indian men
creator: Palmer, Dixon
subject: Kiowa; Choctaw
description: A painting of three blanket wrapped Indian men.  Their heads are turned to the viewer�s left although each one faces a different direction.  The man to the viewer�s left has his body turned partially to his left.  He is wrapped in a black and red blanket and has five feathers in his hair.  The man in the center has his back turned to the viewer and is wearing a blue blanket with designs in red.  He has two feathers in his hair and a bow and quiver hanging across his back.  The man on the right faces to the left and is wearing a green blanket with a wide band of pink at the bottom edge.  He is wearing a roach headdress with two feathers attached and has a shield hanging across his back.

title: �Oklahoma Fancy Dancer�
creator: Wilson, Charles Banks

There are bands of large jingle bells around his upper calves just under his knees.  His knees are bent and his right foot is raised as he dances.  In his left hand he holds a small flute. title: Untitled (Yeibichai dancer)
creator: Begay, Harrison
subject: Navajo
description: A painting of a man (facing the viewer) wearing a Yeibichai mask with thirteen feathers framing it.  The mask has a collar or ruff of evergreen boughs.  The dancer is in a semi-squatting position with both knees bent.  He has a tanned deerskin draped over his right shoulder and tied at his waist on his left side.  He is wearing an orange shirt, brown pants with silver buttons down the side seams and high topped hard soled dance boots.  The tops of the boots are tied up with narrow red hand-woven ties.  He holds evergreen sprigs in his right hand and a leather bag in his left hand.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow by absentee bid at a R.G. Munn Auction held in Albuquerque, New Mexico, February 3, 1995.  This painting is one of twenty purchased by the Zarrows at this auction. Original framer:  Village Frame, Santa Barbara, CA 74171.

title: �Straight Dancer�

subject: Osage

He also wears a purple shirt, a light red scarf around his neck held with a shell slider, a beaded belt, black pants and a black breechclout, two bands of jingle bells around his upper calves, and beaded dance moccasins. title: �Long Hair Hopi Kachina�
creator: Polelonema, Otis
subject: Hopi
description: A painting of two identical dancers (facing the viewer).  They are depicting the Hopi Long Hair Kachina.  They wear the traditional costume � longhair mask, hand-woven and embroidered kilts tied with a hand-woven black, green and red sash, and dance boots.  They also wear two large jingle bells tied to their calves just below their left knee and yellow body paint.  An animal skin (fox) hangs down the back of their kilts and can be seen behind their legs.  They wear a bow guard on their left wrists and hold evergreen boughs in their left hands.  There is a gourd rattle in their right hands.  �Hopi Kachinas� is written at the bottom of the painting.

creator: David, Neil
subject: Hopi; Tewa
description: A painting of four dancers and a drummer.  There is a pottery like border design across the bottom and up the sides of the painting.  Counting from the viewer�s left, the first and fourth dancers are Koshari Clowns, they face the viewer and slightly to the left.  They wear the traditional costume, which includes black and white striped body paint and they show considerable motion as they dance and sing.  The second dancer is male and faces the viewer�s left.  He holds an arrow in his left hand and a rattle in his right.  The third dancer faces the viewer�s left and is female.  She holds a basket tray in her right hand and two feathers in her left hand.  The figure closest to the viewer�s right side of the painting is the drummer and he faces the viewer.  He beats a drum that is suspended at playing height by means of leather straps around his neck.

title: Going south
creator: Chee, Robert

description: A painting of a young Navajo boy sitting on a horse while the horse drinks from a small puddle of water.  Horse and rider face the viewer�s left. The horse also has four white sox.  The bridle is a simple one made of rope and a blanket serves as a saddle.

title: Apache dancer
creator: Cleveland, Fred
subject: Navajo
description: A painting of an Apache Mountain Spirit dancer in dynamic motion painted against a black background.  The dancer�s feet are striding toward the viewer�s right while his upper body is turned to face the viewer.  He wears a headdress and mask.  A red band is tied across the lower half of the mask to which three feathers are attached.  Four white triangles with circles on the point are painted on his chest and he wears a two-layer deerskin kilt held up by a concha belt.  On his feet he wears Apache boots with circular tabs on the toes.  He holds sword like white sticks in his hands and there are long red ribbons tied to and swirling from his forearms.  The figure is backlighted by what appears to be a fire.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow by absentee bid at a R.G. Munn Auction held in Albuquerque, New Mexico, February 5, 1995. title: �Chaco Mug�
creator: McCullough, Michael C.
subject: Choctaw
description: A painting of three reconstructed ceramic pots � one Zuni with a deer design, one Zia with a parrot design and a prehistoric mug (Anasazi) from Chaco Canyon dated AD 1075. provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow from the artist at Mayfest Festival, Tulsa, Oklahoma, May 1996. On dust cover:  artist signature 5/96. After researching the shards, they have been cataloged by the state and returned to companies which have followed state laws which require proper digs of ancient artifacts before building.  The shards are registered as being 1100 � 1250 A.G.  They are displayed just as they were excavated and are not retouched in any way. Sticker:  Michael C. McCullough, Fine Arts, Albuquerque Old Town (505) 242-8667.

title: �Traditional Women�
creator: White Hawk, Laurie Houseman
subject: Winnebago; Santee Sioux
description: A painting of two Lakota women in traditional dress as they participate in a pow wow dance.  They face the viewer�s left one in front of the other.  The woman to the left (viewer�s) wears a headband and a feather in her hair.  She is dressed in an orange, white, red, and yellow beaded decorated buckskin dress with long fringe.  She carries a shawl in the same colors folded over her arms and a feather fan in her hand.  The woman to the right (viewer�s) wears the same clothing but the beading on her dress is dark blue, light blue and red and her shawl is the same colors.  She has a feather in her hair but no headband.  Both wear beaded moccasins and leggings in colors that match their costumes.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow at The Art Market, Tulsa, Oklahoma, march 19, 1999.  At the time the Zarrows purchased this painting Ms. White Hawk was working at The Art Market, although her home is in Lawrence, Kansas, and the Zarrows enjoyed meeting and visiting with her.

creator: Montoya, Geronima
subject: San Juan
description: A stylized design that includes a row of three female figures (upper torso only) whose arms are connected.  All three wear three red chokers and a shell pendent necklace and the traditional one shoulder Pueblo dress. Below these figures is a water serpent design.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow at the Oke Oweenge Crafts cooperative, San Juan Pueblo, New Mexico, March 27, 1992. subject: Navajo

title: �Freeborn Companions�
creator: Williams, David
subject: Kiowa; Tonkawa; Apache
description: A painting of a young boy clinging with his left hand to a bush at the edge of a precipice, a look of alarm on his face.  A rabbit is clutched in the crook of his right arm.  A golden eagle with a rabbit in its claws is about to land to the right of the boy.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow, 9/21/9.  Where it was purchased is not available.  On sticker on front:  David Williams, Freeborn Companions, original painting, no discount. On back of painting:  �Freeborn Companions�, an original painting by David Williams, Rt 1, Tahlequah OK 456-5359. Taped to painting:  �Freeborn Companions�, 9/21/80, The golden eagle depicted here was found injured when very young by the small boy.  He cared for it attentively and raised it to adulthood.  When grown the boy released it from captivity but the eagle never forgot his friend.  They still spent time together, as shown in this painting as they were hunting for rabbits.  Both friends were born free and lived accordingly.

Your thoughtfulness put a special bright spot into our Christmas.  My sister was hoping to get over to Gilcrease to meet you before she had to return to Washington, D.C. but there were so many details to attend to pertaining to Solomon�s death that we were unable to return to the Gilcrease Museum. title: �Cherokee Woman Warrior
creator: Hill, Joan
subject: Creek; Cherokee
description: A round painting of a woman wearing only a breechclout and moccasins riding a rearing white horse while she holds a staff (lance?) with a flag on it.  She and the horse face the viewer's right.  In the background there is a moon, hills, a river, and trees.  In the foreground and in front of the horse are three flags.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow from Indian Paintbrush Gallery, Siloam Springs, AR, December 1980. Sticker on the dust cover:  Indian Paintbrush Gallery, Inc.; Hwy 68 bypass, Box 895, Siloam Springs, AR 72761, phone 501 524 6920. Taped to the dust cover:  "Cherokee Woman Warrior" Ethnology records show several instances, in which the Indian woman joined her men, when many of the warriors had been slain in battle.  They shed their own clothing, put on a loincloth and other accoutrements of the warrior and carried the lance into battle.  One such incident and place is recorded in Cherokee and U.S. history as "War Women's Creek" where several women were found among the dead warriors at battles end.  Joan Hill
