title: Scalp dancer
creator: Crumbo, Woodrow Wilson
subject: Potawatomi
description: A silkscreen of a Plains Indian ceremonial war dancer in full regalia.  As he dances he faces the viewer with his right knee bent and raised waist high and the lower leg slanted to the viewer�s right.  The left knee is bent and the foot is on the floor.  His left arm is bent and he holds a scalp in his left hand.  In the hand of his outstretched and raised right arm he holds a feathered fan.  In addition to black body paint he wears a feathered roach headdress, large feathered arm and tail rosettes, a long red breechclout, and beaded bow guards, lower leg bands, and moccasins.  The sound of ankle bells accompanies his movement.
provenance: N/A Sticker on shrinkwrap:  65.00
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Eagle dancer
creator: Crumbo, Woodrow Wilson
subject: Potawatomi
description: A silkscreen of a Plains Indian eagle dancer in motion.  He faces the viewer with his head turned to the viewer�s left.  His legs are in a side lunge position with his right leg bent and his left straight.  He wears feathered wing like decorations on his arms.  His right arm is curved to the side and up over his head.  His left arm curves down to his left.  He wears blue body paint with designs painted on his legs.  In addition he wears a feathered roach headdress, a beaded collar, beaded arm and lower leg bands and beaded moccasins.

title: untitled  2 seated figures with fans
creator: Geionety, George
subject: Kiowa; Comanche
description: A painting of two Indian men seated facing each other.  They have feathers in their hair and orange paint on their faces.  They both hold feathered beaded fans in their right hands.  The man on the viewer's right is dressed in fringed buckskin and a blue blanket.  The man on the viewer's left is wrapped in a pink and black blanket.  On the ground behind each figure is a box used to hold ceremonial objects.

title: Buffalo dancer
creator: Crumbo, Woodrow Wilson
subject: Potawatomi
description: A silkscreen of a Plains Indian buffalo dancer wearing a buffalo hide complete with horns and tail.  He wears the horns as a headdress and the hide hangs down his back.  Ht faces the viewer�s right as he dances with his right leg bent and raised waist high.  He leans back slightly and looks upward.  The area across his eyes is painted red and white and a red, blue, and black design is painted down the outside of his legs.  He wears a red breechclout and buffalo fur lower leg wraps.  He holds a knife in his right hand and a decorated shield on his left arm.  This painting was done on a gray background.

title: �Dreams Are With Me�
creator: Henderson, Kathy
subject: Cherokee
description: A head and shoulder portrait of an Indian man with long black hair who is wearing face paint.  He faces the viewer and is wrapped in a black blanket what has red and white stripes.  These stripes are on his right shoulder.  His face has white paint on the lower half and blue paint on the upper half.  The blue forms two points that extend from his cheek to his chin.  The margin of the blue paint, where it meats the white, is outlined in red.  Three large feathers are attached to the back of his head.  One feather hangs down toward his left shoulder and two feathers hang down toward his right shoulder.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow at The Art Market, Tulsa, Oklahoma, April 14, 2000. On back of painting:  # 600,  �Dreams -- Are With Me�, K. Henderson.

title: �Study for Sweet Talkin Man�
creator: Snidow, Gordon
description: A study used for a finished painting and a limited edition book.  The study is of a man and a horse in a fenced area.  The sorrel horse (facing viewer�s right) is watching as the man approaches him with a rope in his hand.  The man is wearing a cowboy hat, vest and chaps and he appears to be talking to the horse.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow at the Gilcrease Museum�s �Rendezvous� exhibition, May 12, 1981.  Gordon Snidow was the featured artist.  This book and study were numbered 15 of a limited edition of 50.  A study of different paintings were included with each book.  The original painting of �Sweet Talkin Man� was sold to John Rooney of Tulsa, Oklahoma for $33,500.  Mr. Zarrow representing his company Sooner Pipe and Supply also purchased a sculpture, �Just A Pinch Between Your Teeth and Gum,�  at this exhibition and it was displayed at the corporate headquarters. Written on the bottom margin of the study:  �To my friends Maxine and Jack, Thank you for making my Gilcrease show the highlight of my life�  signed � G. Snidow CA.

title: Untitled � pow-wow fancy dancer
creator: Nevaquaya, Doc Tate
subject: Comanche
description: A painting of a male pow-wow dancer in full regalia.  He faces the viewer�s left and is playing a fully beaded flute that he holds in his right hand.  In his left hand he holds a feather dance fan.  He is wearing beaded gauntlets, arm bands, chest straps, belt, and ankle bands with fur hanging down.  In addition he wears a breach clout with two trailers, two bustles, and jingle bell bands around his legs just below the knees.  His black hair is braided and he wears a roach headdress.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow by means of a mail bid at a R. G. Munn Auction held in Albuquerque, New Mexico, February 4, 2001.  This was one of six paintings purchased at this auction. Auction number:  1282.

title: Untitled � two male, one female Pueblo dancers
creator: Secatero, John
subject: Navajo
description: A painting of three Pueblo buffalo dancers � two males and one female.  The female is in the center of the painting and faces the viewer�s left with her head turned toward the viewer.  She wears the traditional hand-woven embroidered one shoulder dress (left shoulder bare) and a red hand-woven belt.  She holds two feathers in each hand.  The male dancers on each side of her wear hand-woven embroidered armbands and kilts, and buffalo headdresses.  The hand-woven garments are white with colored embroidery (red, green, blue, and black).  The male dancers hold rattles in their right hands and two feathers in their left hands.  In addition they wear bands of jingle bells around their waists and lower legs.  The dancer to the viewer�s left faces the viewer and the dancer to the viewer�s right has his back to the viewer.  The left foot of all three dancers is raised as they dance.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow by means of a mail bid at a R. G. Munn Auction held in Albuquerque, New Mexico, February 4, 2001.  This was one of six paintings purchased at this auction.  Two paintings by Fred Beaver were purchased for Ginger Kingman.

title: Untitled - silversmith
creator: Tsinajinnie, Andrew Van
subject: Navajo
description: A painting of a Navajo Silversmith at work.  He faces the viewer�s right and is seated cross legged on the ground as he hammers a piece of silver that is laying on an anvil.  He has a band tied around his forehead and is wearing a blue shirt and tan pants.  Silver concha belts, silver horse bridle parts, and silver necklaces hang on a bush behind him.  There are sandstone molds on the ground in front of and to his right and a fireplace for heating the silver in front of him.  A bellows lies on the ground by his right knee.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow by means of a mail bid at a R. G. Munn Auction held in Albuquerque, New Mexico, February 2, 2001.  This painting was one of six purchased at this auction.

title: �Navajo Indian Weaver and Silversmith at Monument Valley�
creator: Tsinajinnie, Andrew Van
subject: Navajo
description: A painting of a Navajo woman kneeling in front of a loom as she weaves a rug and of a Navajo man as he makes silver jewelry using an anvil (the woman is to the viewer�s left and the man to the viewer�s right).  The scene takes place in the out of doors in Monument Valley Arizona.  There is a bluff behind them and a tree to the viewer�s left.  The loom hangs from a branch of the tree.  The woman is wearing the traditional Navajo velvet blouse and gathered skirt and her hair is wrapped in a chongo.  Her blouse is burgundy and her skirt blue.  The man is dressed in a blue shirt and gray pants.  He faces the viewer�s right and the woman faces the viewer�s left.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow by means of a mail bid at a R. G. Munn Auction (#501) held in Albuquerque, New Mexico, February 4, 2001. title: Time For Rest
creator: Stubbs, Rosemary
description: A painting of a wooden wheeled piece of farm equipment (wagon?) resting in the grass by the corner of an old stone building.  An old tree spreads its branches over it.  A prickly pear cactus is located by the right (viewer's) wheel and a yucca plant is in the lower right corner.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow at the County Osage Art Exhibit and Sale, Pawhuska, OK, June 20, 1981.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Night Dancer
creator: Rabbit, Bill
subject: Cherokee
description: A painting of a powwow fancy war dancer painted against a black background.  The dancer faces the viewer's left.  He is wearing a feather rocker headdress, upper and lower back feathered bustles, and feathered arm bands.  He is also wearing a blue vest and blue breechclout, blue gauntlets on both arms, and moccasins.  He has jingle bells on both legs.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow at the Gentry Gallery, Tulsa, OK, October 19, 1980.  The exhibition was held by the gallery and the McDonnellDouglas Tulsa Management Club as an Indian Scholarship fund raiser for the Oklahoma Indian Art Program.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Three brothers
creator: Belindo, Dennis (Aun-So-Te)
subject: Kiowa; Navajo
description: A painting of three men dancing (powwow fancy war dance?).  They are dancing back to back thus face three different directions  one faces the viewer.  All three are wearing roach style headdresses with two feathers attached and red cloth capes.  The one facing the viewer is wearing a pipe bone choker, a pipe bone breast plate, leather leggings, a red breechclout, and beaded moccasins.  Each dancer is holding a feathered staff and the facing dancer has a beaded feather fan in his left hand.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow at the Oklahoma Indian Art Gallery, Oklahoma City, OK, March 21, 1992.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: The Philosopher
creator: Holtz, Itshak J.
description: A portrait of an older bearded man (facing the viewer's right) with the forefinger of his right hand resting on his cheek.  He appears to be contemplating serious matters.  He is wearing a black skull cap.
provenance: This lithograph was a gift to Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow from their daughter, Kathy Zarrow.  She purchased it at a gallery in Washington, D.C. On dust cover:  June 1971 and data on the artist. Itshak J. Holtz Born:  Poland, 1925. Studied: Bezalel Academy of Art Jerusalem, Israel, The Art Student, S League of New York National Academy of Design, New York. Exhibitions: Ahda Artzt Gallery, New York, Allied Artists of America, New York City, Audobon Artists, New York City, Continental Art Gallery, New York City, Hall of Art, New York City, Karlegach Gallery, Fair Lawn, New Jersey, National Academy of Design, New York City, Portrait Inc., New York City, Roslyn Village Gallelry, Roslyn, New York, The Crane Korchin Galleries, Bala Cynwyd, PA, The Little Studio, New York City, Wiener Gallery, New York City. One Man Shows: Theodor Herzl Institute, New York City, Wiener Gallery, New York City. Collections: Represented in many collections throughout the United States and Israel.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Wisdom
creator: Annesley, Robert
subject: Cherokee
description: Silverpoint drawing of an older woman's face.  She faces the viewer and looks down.  She is wearing pierced earrings with round pendants.

title: Old man with memories (�I was there�)
creator: Annesley, Robert
subject: Cherokee
description: A portrait of a gray haired man wearing a cowboy hat and a sheep skin collared jacket.  He faces the viewer's right.  The horizon suggests cattle and a man on horseback.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow at The Art Market, Tulsa, Oklahoma, September 27, 1981. On invoice: �painting of Austin Doolittle, working cowboy from Seminole, Texas. From phone call made by Jack Zarrow to Bob Annesley, February 8, 1999:   Bob remembered the drawing and stated that the subject was Austin Doolittle of Seminole, Texas.  At 76 years of age, he was the oldest working cowboy in Texas when the painting was done in 1981.   Bob also indicated that the drawing�s current value should be in the neighborhood of $2,100.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Nature's Treats
creator: Stroud, Virginia
subject: Cherokee; Creek
description: A painting of four women and nine young girls picking and eating sunflower seeds.  They are in the middle of a field of very large Sunflowers.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow from the artist at an exhibition, "Winds Of Change" held at South Boston Company, Tulsa, OK, January, 14, 1999.  The exhibition was to announce Ms. Stroud's intention to run for Principal Chief of the Cherokee and a portion of the sales were donated to her campaign. On dust cover:  "For Jack and Maxine, Thank You for your years of support.  Enjoy!  Virginia Stroud 1 99.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: unknown � landscape with tree and pond
creator: Garza, Manuel
description: It is a landscape  there is a tree on the viewer's right and a pond on the left.  There are hills in the background and wild flowers in the foreground.  Three rocks  2 large, 1 small  are in the lower left.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow at the Wagner Gallery, Austin, TX on March 26, 1980.

title: War Dance
creator: Sweezy, Carl
subject: Arapaho
description: A painting of a powwow fancy war dancer.  His back is to the viewer.  His left hand is raised toward the viewer's upper left and his right hand, holding a feather fan, is pointed toward the lower right.  His head is turned toward the viewer�s right.  The dancer is wearing a red breechclout, a feather bustle, feathered arm bands, moccasins, and a feathered roach headdress.  An arrow is painted in beneath the dancer.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow at the Art Market, Tulsa, OK, February 8, 1992. Note in File:  "2/25/92 Information given to us by Linda Greever   Art Market, Tulsa, OK.  Carl Sweezy painting was in estate of Nelson Miles' grandson (Civil War person) on permanent loan to Pawnee Bill Trading Post Museum.  Museum closed down and pieces were sold at auction.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Corn Dance
creator: Naha, Raymond
subject: Hopi
description: A painting of three dancing figures wearing three different Kachina masks.  They are also wearing embroidered handwoven breechclouts over shorts, spruce bough neck ruffs and arm decorations, and dance moccasins.  They have jingle bells tied around their upper calves.  The dancer on the viewer's left has his back to the viewer, the dancer in the middle faces the viewer and the dancer to the viewer's right faces the viewer's left.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow at The Art Market's "Sale of Important Art", Tulsa, OK, April 12, 1991.  This painting was one of six paintings purchased at that time. Jeanne Snodgrass King, Tulsa, Oklahoma, previously owned this painting.  It was a gift of appreciation to her from the Philbrook Museum Volunteers when she left the museum in 1968.  The volunteers had purchased it at Philbrook�s �Indian Annual.�  In the mid �80s Mrs. King sold it to Jack Wilson, a Tulsa Geologist and avid collector of Indian Art.  Mr. Wilson later sold the majority of his collection at The Art Market�s �Sale of Important Art� where the Zarrows bought it. Sticker on dust cover:  Raymond Naha  11 1/4 X 16 1/2  "Corn Dance", watercolor.  purch. March 1991.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow at The Art Market's "Sale of Important Art", Tulsa, OK, April 12, 1991.  This painting was one of six paintings purchased.

title: Peace Prayer
creator: Williams, David Emmett
subject: Kiowa; Tonkawa; Apache
description: A painting of a man in a buffalo headdress sitting on a pinto horse.  He appears to be singing and is lifting a peace pipe skyward in his left hand.  There is snow on the ground.
provenance: Purchased by Jack Zarrow from David Williams out of the back of  his truck at the Creek County fair grounds, Sapulpa, OK, October 20, 1979. Mounted on the dust cover:  "Peace Prayer"  Oct. 21, 1979, original painting by David Williams (#1738 framers number).

title: Traditional Comanche Dancer
creator: Watchetaker, George Smith "Woogie"
subject: Comanche
description: A painting of a single dancer facing the viewer's left.  It is painted on blue mat board.  In addition to a breechclout and moccasins the dancer is wearing a feathered roach headdress, a feather bustle, and feather decorated armbands.  His left arm is raised and his left hand holds a feather fan while his left leg is raised to his waist as he dances.  There is a teepee in the background to the viewer's left.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow from Oklahoma Indian Art Gallery, Oklahoma City, OK, January 18, 1981. Attached to dust cover:  "Traditional Comanche Dancer"  1/1981 $160 W 1811 Fancy War Dancer; Oklahoma Indian Art Gallery; "Woogie" Watchetaker; 9 1/2" X 15" Image, tempera on board.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: untitled  man on horseback
creator: Saul, Terry C.
subject: Choctaw; Chickasaw
description: A painting of a man in buckskins who is riding a paint horse bareback.  He holds the single rein of a war bridle in his right hand and a shield and spear in his left hand.  He and the horse are running (to the viewer's left) as he looks behind them.  They are between two stylized bushes.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow at The Art Market, Tulsa, OK, July 14, 1991. Old sticker attached to new dust cover:  �July 1964; Tulsa Pow Wow Club, 1422 South Quincy; Davis Mirror and Frame Gallery, 2314 E 15th St, Tulsa, Ok  WE6 4848.

title: Fire dance
creator: Chee, Robert
subject: Navajo
description: A painting on black mat board of four men dancing around a fire.  Three of the men whose skin is painted blue are wearing only a breechclout and have a scarf tied over their head.  The forth man is fully dressed in a shirt, trousers, and moccasins  his exposed skin is also blue.  The three men in breechclouts are dancing around the fire, the forth man is dancing toward (and faces) the viewer's right.  Four Navajo women and four Navajo women, wrapped in blankets as they watch the dance, are in the background.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow from The Art Market's "Sale of Important Art" held March 7 through March 21, 1991 in Tulsa, OK (invoice date 4/12/91).  One of six paintings they purchased at this sale.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Cheyenne Buffalo Dance  Modern
creator: Goodbear, Paul J.
subject: Cheyenne
description: A stylized painting of a dancer wearing a buffalo headdress.  His arms and legs are black and he is wearing a vest, breechclout, and beaded moccasins.  He faces the viewer's left and holds a rattle in his left hand.  As he dances he is bent double and his left leg almost touches his chest.  This painting has an Art Deco look.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow at The Art Market, Tulsa, OK, April 26, 1995. Written under painting and badly faded: "Cheyenne Buffalo Dance Modern, by Chief Flying Eagle '39 On dust cover:  Chief Flying Eagle   Paul J. Goodbear; "Cheyenne Buffalo Dance."

title: A Dance For Brother Elk (Santa Clara Elk Dancer)
creator: Padilla, Fernando, Jr.
subject: Navajo; San Felipe
description: A painting of a single dancer facing the viewer and moving toward the viewer's left.  He is wearing an elk horn headdress, a white shirt, a white, red, and black kilt, a sash with jingle bells and a feather bustle, white knit leggings, and dance moccasins.  In his hands he holds two blue feather decorated sticks that he is using like the forelegs of an elk.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow at The Art Market, Tulsa, OK, April 12, 1991. On dust cover:  "April 12, 1991; Fernando Padilla "A Dance For Brother Elk" (Santa Clara Elk Dancer) Pastels and Prismacolor.

creator: Seely, Alice Warder
description: A some what abstract painting of a Northwest Coast Indian man in ceremonial regalia  a bird helmet on his head and two ceremonial objects (rattle and bird carving) typical of the Northwest coast in his hands.

title: untitled  three dancing figures
creator: Herrera, Velino Shije  Ma Pe Wi
subject: Zia
description: A painting of three crouched dancing figures facing the viewer's left.  The figure on the far left is wearing a "war" bonnet, a green kilt with a concho belt and a jingle bell belt, and moccasins.  His body is painted blue and yellow and he holds a painted shield in his left hand and a stone hatchet in his right.  Behind him (in the center) is a figure wearing a roach and painted black with red stripes on his face.  This figure is wearing a red breechclout and has a spear in his left hand.  The figure farthest to the viewer's right is wearing a "war" bonnet, a red kilt, and moccasins.  He is painted blue and yellow and holds a feather shield in his left hand.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow by mail from James Conlon, Albuquerque, NM, March 10, 1992. On dust cover:  Datus E Myers  Artist   Velino Shije; Velino Shije Herrera, Ma Pe Wi, oriole (or Red Bird) Zia Pueblo.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Fancy dancer
creator: Crumbo, Woodrow Wilson
subject: Potawatomi
description: A painting of a pow-wow fancy dancer dancing toward the viewer.  He is wearing a buffalo headdress with a roach and eagle feathers attached.  In addition he wears a blue vest with matching gantlets, leg bands, and moccasins and a red breechclout.  Animal tails appear to be attached to arm and leg bands.  In his left hand he holds a shield and in his right hand a spear.  As he dances his left leg is kicked back and his arms are raised.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow from Howard Huston of Hurst, TX, June 2, 1995.  One of three PURCHASED: that included two by Joe Herrera. Data given the Zarrows by Howard Huston:  "Thurlow Laurance (compos. "Waters of Minnetonka") met Woody & brought him to Wichita University for schooling and to illustrate a book of Indian melodies.  Thurlow was head of the music dept. at the university. After Thurlow's death his wife (Edna) had all the pictures that were left.  (Thurlow had destroyed many of them while he was ill). Woody had given Edna several paintings (including this one).  When she had to give up & go to a one-room apt. - she got rid of everything - rugs, jewelry, pots etc.  We (my sister & I - friends of hers) were given 3 paintings.  One of them was done on a deer hide (we gave it back after we moved into a smaller place). Betty Crawford 8030 E. Girard #612 Denver, CO  80231
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Figures From Buffalo Ceremony
creator: Roybal, Alfonso - Awa Tsireh
subject: San Ildefonso
description: A painting of two flat, static figures facing the viewer.  The one on the viewer's left (male) is wearing a buffalo headdress and a tan kilt.  In his left hand he holds a bow and arrow and in his right hand a gourd rattle.  The figure on the viewer's right (female) is dressed in a hand-woven embroidered blouse and skirt.  In addition she is wearing a rain sash around her waist and a large circle of feathers on her back (bustle like).  She holds two feathers in each hand.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow from James Conlon in Santa Fe, NM, September 1992. On dust cover:  "Figures From Buffalo Ceremony" by Awa Twsireh or Alfonso Roybal" purchased 1992.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Drying pumpkins
creator: Bales, Jean
subject: Iowa
description: A painting of fifteen women peeling and drying pumpkin rings.  At the top of the painting there are drying racks with six women hanging pumpkin rings on them.  At the bottom are ten women working with a pile of pumpkins (they are green and white, not orange although the meat is orange).  In the middle area are two white dogs and two young girls chasing one another.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow at the Indian Paintbrush Gallery in Siloam Springs, AR, October, 27, 1980. On dust cover:  "About 1979-80?  watercolor on rice paper, "Drying Pumpkins" by Jean Bales Iowa"
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: untitled - crouching Apache warrior
creator: Palmer, Ignatius
subject: Mescalero Apache
description: A painting of an Indian man dressed in a blue breechclout, leather leggings, and high topped moccasins (Apache boots).  He is crouched down and appears to be moving toward the viewer's left.  His upper body is twisted and his head turned to the viewer's right.  He holds a shield in his left hand and a spear in his right.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow by absentee bid at a R.B. Munn auction in Albuquerque, NM, February 4, 1995.  This was one of fourteen paintings PURCHASED: at this auction.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Cayote At The Mall
creator: McMurtry, Robert
subject: Comanche
description: A painting of an indoor mall with seven familiar stores depicted in the background and a coyote dressed in cowboy clothing standing in the foreground.  Various cartoon characters are strolling around the stores.  The title of the painting is painted at the bottom as part of a border.  There are large spangles on pins attached to a storefront in the center of the painting.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow at The Art Market, Tulsa, OK, September 9, 1991.  One of four paintings purchased at this time.  The others were by Mootzka, Joe Herrera and Able Sanchez.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Peyote Ceremony
creator: Momaday, Al
subject: Kiowa
description: A painting of two couples (a man and a woman) seated on two sides of a fire built on a Native American Church alter with a peyote bud also on the alter.  In each couple the woman is the closest to the viewer, the man is toward the back and slightly ahead.  The woman in the couple to the viewer's left is wearing a red shawl and the man is wrapped in a black blanket.  Their heads are bowed and they each hold a beaded feather fan in their left hands.  In the couple to the viewer's right the woman is wrapped in a black blanket and her head is bowed as she holds a beaded feather fan.  The man is wearing a buckskin shirt and is wrapped in a red blanket.  His head is raised and his hands are out stretched with the left hand holding a ceremonial rattle, staff, and fan.  A peyote bud and three waterbirds are in the sky above the smoke from the fire.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow at The Art Market's "Sale of Important Art� which was held March 7 through 21, 1991.  This purchase was made April 12, 1991.  This was one of six paintings purchased at this sale.  The others were by R. Hood, R. Chee, JD Roybal, R. Naha, and M. Lomakema. Previous owners: This painting was given to Jeanne Snodgrass (King) by Al Momaday while she was working at Philbrook Museum, Tulsa, OK.  She later sold it to Indian Art collector Jack Wilson of Tulsa, OK.  When he broke up his collection he sold it at The Art Market's Sale of Important Art in 1991 where it was purchased by the arrows. On dust cover: "Peyote Ceremony" by Al MomadayOn sticker:  �Al Momaday; "Peyote Ceremony"  19 1/2" X 25" tempera�

title: �Eagle Omen
creator: Seabourn, Bert D.
subject: Cherokee
description: A painting of an eagle with wings spread toward the top and the bottom of the painting.  A wrinkled face is superimposed over the breast of the eagle.  There is a moon just above the eagles head.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow at the Five Civilized Tribes Museum's 1980 Masters Art Show where it was exhibited, November 16, 1980. Artists sticker on the dust cover:  "Eagle Omen"; Seabourn.  Artist Bert D. Seabourn Studio, 6105 Covington Lane, Oklahoma City, OK  73132  405 722 1631.

title: Untitled (Indian man on lunging horse)
creator: Bosin, Francis Blackbear
subject: Kiowa; Comanche
description: A painting of an Indian man riding a frightened gray horse that is frantically lunging or bucking to get out of a bog.  The horse's right rear leg is stuck in the mud.  The Indian man is struggling to stay on the horse.  His hair is braided and he is wearing a red breechclout and moccasins.  A shield hangs across his chest.  A buffalo hide is being used as a saddle.  A spear lies in the mud almost under the feet of the horse.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow from Robert P. Clinton and his mother, Mrs. T.P. Clinton, of Tulsa, OK, on December 30, 1998.  This is one of two Bosin paintings the Zarrow's purchased from the Clintons.  The Clintons had purchased the paintings from the artist.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Trail marker
creator: Bosin, Francis Blackbear
subject: Kiowa; Comanche
description: A painting of two Indian men on horses.  The man on the viewer's right faces the viewer's right and is wearing a white buffalo headdress with feather trimmed trailers.  He holds the horses war bridle rein and a beaded pipe bag in his right hand.  There is a feather-decorated staff in his left hand.  His boot moccasins and a knife scabbard at his waist are beaded.  The man on the viewer's left who's horse also faces the viewer's left is wearing a brown fur hat and a red breechclout.  In addition he is wearing beaded hair bands, gantlets, belt and moccasins (the horses nose bands are also beaded).  He holds a staff in his right hand and a bow and arrows in a scabbard in his right hand.  He is looking to his left.  A decorated buffalo skull is in the foreground
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow from Robert P. Clinton and his mother, Mrs. T.P. Clinton, of Tulsa, OK on December 20, 1998.  This painting is one of two Bosin paintings that they purchased from the Clintons.  The Clintons originally purchased the paintings from the artist.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Snow Bird Dance
creator: Vigil, Romando  Tse-Ye-Mu
subject: San Ildefonso
description: A painting of two Pueblo dancers facing the viewer's left.  the one on the viewer's left looks to the left and the one on the right looks toward the viewer.  In their right hands they hold a rattle and in their left hands a bow.  They wear a fur ruff around their necks, white shirts, turquoise necklaces, white hand-woven embroidered kilts, rain sashes, white knit stockings, dance moccasins, and jingle bells (around their calves).  There is a stylized bird in the sky and a decorative design across the bottom of the painting.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow from Gallery 10, Scottsdale, AZ, January 13, 1991.  One of seven paintings purchased by the Zarrows at this time.  These included two others by Romando Vigil and one each by J.D. Roybal, T. Vigil, Duane Dishta, and Popovi Da.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Corn dance
creator: Blue Eagle, Acee
subject: Creek; Pawnee
description: A painting of four Pueblo figures, two male and two females.  The male figure on the far left (viewer's) is dressed in fringed buckskin and a "war" bonnet (Plains Indian style clothing).  He holds a large drum with his left hand and beats it with the drumstick in his right hand.  He and the two figures in front of him face the viewer's right.  In front of the first figure is a dancing female figure dressed in traditional Pueblo ceremonial clothing holding two feathers in each of her hands.  In front of her is a dancing male figure wearing a buffalo headdress, kilt, sash, and dance moccasins.  He holds a bow in his left hand and a rattle in his right.  The forth figure is female (closest to the viewer's right side of the painting) and faces the viewer's left.  She wears a blue blouse, multi-colored striped skirt, plaid pants, and moccasins.  She holds a bow in her left hand and a Spruce branch in her right.  She appears to be singing.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow from Wes Gan of Native American Art, Tulsa, OK, March 17, 1992.  Mr. Wes Gan received the painting from K.E. Gan, Bartlesville, OK who had purchased it from Mae Abbot.  Mae Abbot, a close friend of Acee Blue Eagle, received the painting from him.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Forest Fire
creator: McCombs, Solomon
subject: Creek
description: A painting of a forest fire.  The forest is burning in the background while animals and people flee it in the foreground.  The people and animals are moving toward the viewer's right.  To the viewer's far left are a pair of foxes, then two bears that are standing on their hind legs by a tree.  Just to the right of the tree is a woman carrying a baby and ahead of her (to the right) is a man running with a green tree branch in his hands.  A running deer is at the bottom right (viewer's) edge of the painting.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow from D.F Henry Company, Tulsa,  Oklahoma, December 12 15, 1980. This painting was exhibited at The Gilcrease Museum in the Fred Beaver/Solomon McCombs Memorial Exhibition held March 7, through April 19, 1981.  The Zarrows were one of the sponsors of this exhibition. On dust cover (sticker at top):  Solomon McCombs (1913-1980) Forest Fire; casein, 1976; collection:  Maxine and Jack Zarrow Glued to dust cover:  Newspaper article � �Creek Tribal Leader Dies�,  November 18, 1980.

title: Dog Solder's Challenge
creator: West, Dick/Wah-pah-nah-yah
subject: Cheyenne
description: A painting of an Indian warrior wearing an elaborate headdress.  He stands facing the viewer with his legs spread and his right arm raised.  In his right hand he holds a bow and arrows.  His left-hand holds a feather-decorated spear whose tip is resting on a feather decorated trailer (scarf like).  He is wearing beaded leggings and a red breechclout.  One end of the feather decorated trailer hangs over his left shoulder and across his chest.  A fur belt hangs around his hips.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow at the Gentry Gallery, Tulsa, OK, October 31, 1980.  The exhibition was held as an Indian scholarship fundraiser for the Oklahoma Indian Art Program.  The exhibition  was sponsored by the Gentry Gallery and the McDonnell-Douglas Management Club.  The Zarrows purchased four paintings at this exhibition.  In addition to this one, they purchased works by Jimmie Fife, Burgess Roye, and Jeanne Rorex.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Ribbon Dance - Green Corn Ceremony
creator: Pahsetopah, Paul
subject: Osage; Cherokee
description: A painting of five dancing women with multi-colored long ribbons in their hair and hanging down their backs.  Eight men (backs to the viewer) in wide brimmed hats sit on benches under a brush covered shelter watching the dancers.  There are three other men in the foreground also watching.  Between the two groups a little girl stands sucking her thumb while she watches.  The dancers move to the viewer's right.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow from Paul PahseTopah, March 11, 1981. title: Zia Eagle Dancers
creator: Medina, Rafael
subject: Zia Pueblo
description: A painting of two dancers with eagle headdresses and eagle feather capes across their backs and attached to their arms.  They wear hand-woven embroidered kilts and hand-woven sashes.  The dancer to the viewer's right faces the viewer's left and dances with his left foot on the ground (right raised) and arms out stretched. The dancer to the viewer's left faces the viewer (head turned to his left) and is crouched down with his arms extended.  There is a ceramic effigy bowl on the ground between the dancers and spirit images of the dancers changing to eagles come out of it and appear in the sky.  Two ceramic pots are on the ground on either side of the dancers.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow from Tom Woodard at his home in Santa Fe, New Mexico in March of 1992.  Mr. Woodard had purchased the painting from Rafael Medina in 1976 when Woodard was trying to collect enough of Rafael Medina's pintings for a one-man show.  The show never took place because the artist didn't furnish enough paintings.  According to Mr. Woodard the artist wasn't dependable.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Dancing Before The Hunt
creator: Hunt, Wolf Robe
subject: Acoma
description: A painting of two rows of ten Pueblo dancers.  Seven wear headdresses representing animals. The top row is made up of four dancers representing three antelope and a mountain sheep.  The one on the viewer's far left faces the viewer's right, the other three face the viewer's left.  The bottom row consists of four dancers and two drummers.  The dancer on the bottom row left (viewer's) faces the left and is a deer dancer.  Next on the bottom row are the two drummers.  The next dancer wears a buffalo headdress and faces the viewer�s right.  Also facing right the next dancer is a female.  The last dancer to the right on the bottom row is another dancer in a buffalo headdress - he faces the viewer's right.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow from Wes Gan at Native American Art, Tulsa, OK, May 11, 1998.  According to Mr. Gan,  the artist sold this painting to Field's Fine Art, Tulsa, OK.  Field's sold it to Bob Matheson, Tulsa, OK.  From Mr. Matheson the painting went to Ron Williams, Atlanta, Georgia.  Mr. Wes Gan obtained it from Mr. Williams. On dust cover: From ARTIST: to Fields Fine Arts, Tulsa, OK to Bob Matheson, Tulsa, OK to Ron Williams, Atlanta, GA On dust Cover:  "Dancing Before The Hunt" circe: mid 1960's; ARTIST: Wolf Robe Hunt (Acoma) from Native American Art - Wes Gan, 317 S. title: Hopi with Moata
creator: Cannon, T. C.
subject: Caddo; Kiowa; Choctaw
description: A portrait of a Hopi woman wearing a traditional hair style (exaggerated).  It shows the woman from the waist up, facing the viewer.  She is wearing a hand-woven black blanket/dress and a striped purple shawl.  A multi-strand necklace forms a choker around her neck.  The area behind her is covered with cream and gold horizontal stripes.
provenance: A gift to Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow from Geri and Stan to celebrate the Zarrow's 50th anniversary, 1997. Note in file:  T.C. Cannon's last signed woodcut, ca. 1970
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives
